text: Introduction
label: HH2

text: Welcome to the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework: A Guide to Self-Certification. It is our hope that the
label: BODY

text: Guide will provide U.S. organizations with a better understanding of the purpose and process of self-
label: BODY

text: certifying compliance with the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework. Additional information is available on
label: BODY

text: our website: http://export.gov/safeharbor/
label: BODY

text: In the Guide, we have outlined the critical components of the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework. We
label: BODY

text: have included not only Helpful Hints on Self-Certifying Compliance, but also a copy of the certification
label: BODY

text: form. The Safe Harbor Privacy Principles and frequently asked questions (FAQs) have also been
label: BODY

text: provided for easy reference. In addition, we have included several examples of organization privacy
label: BODY

text: policies. Finally, we have provided a list of third-party dispute resolution providers and a glossary of key
label: BODY

text: terms. The Guide is divided into nine major sections. What follows is a brief description of each section:
label: BODY

text: Overview: The Overview provides background on the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework, including how
label: H4

text: it came about, the benefits of participation, and the basic eligibility criteria. The Overview also provides a
label: BODY

text: summary of what the Safe Harbor Privacy Principles require.
label: BODY

text: Helpful Hints on Self-Certifying Compliance: The Helpful Hints are meant to provide quick answers to
label: BODY

text: questions U.S. organizations might have about the self-certification process, but this resource should be
label: BODY

text: used in conjunction with the rest of the material covered in the Guide. The Helpful Hints also serve as a
label: BODY

text: checklist, which should be reviewed to evaluate an organization’s readiness to self-certify.
label: BODY

text: Safe Harbor Privacy Principles: We have provided the full text of the official declaration of the Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor Privacy Principles, as announced on February 16, 2009. This text is helpful in understanding the
label: BODY

text: foundation of the Safe Harbor Privacy Principles and the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework.
label: BODY

text: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs): The FAQs and answers, which clarify and supplement the Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor Privacy Principles, address many of the most commonly asked questions about the U.S.-Swiss
label: BODY

text: Safe Harbor Framework.
label: BODY

text: Certification Form: We have provided the Certification Form for easy reference, as it serves as the self-
label: BODY

text: certification application form.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Once submitted and approved, a completed certification form serves as a participating organization’s
label: BODY

text: Safe Harbor List record. Applicants should apply online via our website (i.e. click on the “Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: Login / Certification Form” link on the left navigation bar: https://safeharbor.export.gov/login.aspx).
label: BODY

text: Sample Privacy Policies: We have provided three sample privacy policies, which may serve as
label: BODY

text: guidance when creating a new privacy policy or updating an existing one to conform to the U.S.-Swiss
label: BODY

text: Safe Harbor Framework. Relevant privacy policies must include an affirmative commitment to the Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor Privacy Principles and the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework.
label: BODY

text: Dispute Resolution and Enforcement Options: We have provided a short description of the role of
label: BODY

text: third-party dispute resolution providers (also referred to as ‘independent recourse mechanisms’), a list of
label: BODY

text: such providers, and descriptions of the services provided by three of the listed providers.
label: BODY

text: Glossary: A short glossary is also provided for many of the technical terms frequently used in the Guide.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Overview
label: HH3

text: Background on the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: The Swiss Federal Act on Data Protection (FADP) went into effect in July 1993, and important
label: BODY

text: modifications in January 2008. The FADP would prohibit the transfer of personal data to countries that do
label: BODY

text: not meet Switzerland’s “adequacy” standard for privacy protection.
label: BODY

text: While the United States and Switzerland share the goal of enhancing privacy protection for their citizens,
label: BODY

text: the United States takes a different approach to privacy from that taken by Switzerland. The United States
label: BODY

text: uses a sectoral approach that relies on a mix of legislation, regulation, and self-regulation. Switzerland,
label: BODY

text: however, relies on comprehensive legislation that requires, among other things, the creation of an
label: BODY

text: independent government data protection agency, registration of databases with this agency, and in some
label: BODY

text: instances prior approval before personal data processing may begin. As a result of these differences, the
label: BODY

text: comprehensive procedures set forth in Swiss law could have impacted the ability of U.S. organizations to
label: BODY

text: engage in a range of transactions with Switzerland.
label: BODY

text: In order to bridge these differences and provide a streamlined and cost-effective means for U.S.
label: BODY

text: organizations to satisfy the Act’s “adequacy” requirement, the U.S. Department of Commerce in
label: BODY

text: consultation with the Federal Data Protection and Information Commissioner of Switzerland developed a
label: BODY

text: "Safe Harbor" framework. This arrangement was developed in accordance with the U.S.-Swiss Trade and
label: BODY

text: Investment Cooperation Forum that had been established in 2006. The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: Framework, which was approved by Switzerland in 2009, is an important way for U.S. organizations to
label: BODY

text: avoid experiencing interruptions in their business dealings with Switzerland or facing prosecution by
label: BODY

text: Swiss authorities under Swiss privacy law. Self-certifying to the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework will
label: BODY

text: ensure that Swiss organizations know that your organization provides "adequate" privacy protection, as
label: BODY

text: defined by Swiss law.
label: BODY

text: U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Benefits
label: HH1

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor program provides a number of important benefits to U.S. and Swiss
label: BODY

text: organizations.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Benefits for participating U.S. organizations include:
label: BODY

text: Participating organizations will be deemed to provide “adequate” privacy protection;
label: BODY

text: Swiss requirements for prior approval of data transfers either will be waived or approval will be
label: BODY

text: automatically granted; and
label: BODY

text: Claims brought by Swiss citizens against U.S. organizations will be heard, subject to limited
label: BODY

text: exceptions, in the U.S.; and
label: BODY

text: Compliance requirements are streamlined and cost-effective, which should particularly benefit
label: BODY

text: small and medium enterprises.
label: BODY

text: A Swiss organization can ensure that it is sending information to a U.S. organization participating in the
label: BODY

text: U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor program by viewing the public list of Safe Harbor organizations posted on the
label: BODY

text: Safe Harbor website. This list contains the names of all U.S. organizations that have self-certified to the
label: BODY

text: U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework. This list will be regularly updated, so that it is clear which
label: BODY

text: organizations are assured of Safe Harbor benefits.
label: BODY

text: How does an organization join?
label: BODY

text: The decision by U.S. organizations to enter the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor program is entirely voluntary.
label: BODY

text: Organizations that decide to participate in the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor program must comply with the
label: BODY

text: U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework and publicly declare that they do so. To be assured of Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: benefits, an organization must self-certify annually in writing to the Department of Commerce that it
label: BODY

text: agrees to adhere to the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor program requirements, which include elements such as
label: BODY

text: notice, choice, access, and enforcement. It must also state in its published privacy policy statement that it
label: BODY

text: complies with the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework and that it has certified its adherence to the Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor Privacy Principles. The Department of Commerce maintains a list of the organizations that file
label: BODY

text: self-certification letters and makes both the list and the self-certification letters publicly available.
label: BODY

text: To qualify for the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor, an organization can either join a self-regulatory privacy
label: BODY

text: program that adheres to the Safe Harbor’s requirements or develop its own self-regulatory privacy policy
label: BODY

text: that conforms to the Safe Harbor.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Moreover, only those organizations subject to the jurisdiction of the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) or
label: BODY

text: U.S. air carriers and ticket agents subject to the jurisdiction of the Department of Transportation (DoT)
label: BODY

text: may participate in the Safe Harbor. Organizations generally not subject to FTC jurisdiction include certain
label: BODY

text: financial institutions (e.g. banks, investment houses, credit unions, and savings & loan institutions),
label: BODY

text: telecommunication common carriers, labor associations, non-profit organizations, agricultural co-
label: BODY

text: operatives, and meat processing facilities. In addition, the FTC’s jurisdiction with regard to insurance
label: BODY

text: activities is limited to certain circumstances. If you are uncertain as to whether your organization falls
label: BODY

text: under the jurisdiction of either the FTC or DoT, as certain exceptions to general ineligibility do exist, be
label: BODY

text: sure to contact those agencies for more information.
label: BODY

text: What do the Safe Harbor Privacy Principles require?
label: BODY

text: Organizations must comply with the seven Safe Harbor Privacy Principles, which require the following:
label: BODY

text: 1. Notice
label: BODY

text: Organizations must notify individuals about the purposes for which they collect and use information about
label: BODY

text: them. They must provide information about how individuals can contact the organization with any
label: BODY

text: inquiries or complaints, the types of third parties to which they disclose the information and the choices
label: BODY

text: and means the organization offers for limiting its use and disclosure.
label: BODY

text: 2. Choice
label: BODY

text: Organizations must give individuals the opportunity to choose (opt out) whether their personal information
label: BODY

text: will be disclosed to a third party or used for a purpose incompatible with the purpose for which it was
label: BODY

text: originally collected or subsequently authorized by the individual. For sensitive information, affirmative or
label: BODY

text: explicit (opt in) choice must be given if the information is to be disclosed to a third party or used for a
label: BODY

text: purpose other than its original purpose or the purpose authorized subsequently by the individual.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: 3. Onward Transfer (Transfers to Third Parties)
label: BODY

text: To disclose information to a third party, organizations must apply the notice and choice principles. Where
label: BODY

text: an organization wishes to transfer information to a third party that is acting as an agent, it may do so if it
label: BODY

text: makes sure that the third party subscribes to the Safe Harbor Privacy Principles or is subject to the FADP
label: BODY

text: or another adequacy finding. As an alternative, the organization can enter into a written agreement with
label: BODY

text: such third party requiring that the third party provide at least the same level of privacy protection as is
label: BODY

text: required by the relevant principles.
label: BODY

text: 4. Access
label: BODY

text: Individuals must have access to personal information about themselves that an organization holds and be
label: BODY

text: able to correct, amend, or delete that information where it is inaccurate, except where the burden or
label: BODY

text: expense of providing access would be disproportionate to the risks to the individual’s privacy in the case
label: BODY

text: in question, or where the rights of persons other than the individual would be violated.
label: BODY

text: 5. Security
label: BODY

text: Organizations must take reasonable precautions to protect personal information from loss, misuse and
label: BODY

text: unauthorized access, disclosure, alteration and destruction.
label: BODY

text: 6. Data integrity
label: BODY

text: Personal information must be relevant for the purposes for which it is to be used. An organization should
label: BODY

text: take reasonable steps to ensure that data is reliable for its intended use, accurate, complete, and current.
label: BODY

text: 7. Enforcement
label: BODY

text: In order to ensure compliance with the Safe Harbor Privacy Principles, there must be (a) readily available
label: BODY

text: and affordable independent recourse mechanisms so that each individual’s complaints and disputes can
label: BODY

text: be investigated and resolved and damages awarded where the applicable law or private sector initiatives
label: BODY

text: so provide; (b) procedures for verifying that the commitments organizations make to adhere to the Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor Privacy Principles have been implemented; and (c) obligations to remedy problems arising out of
label: BODY

text: a failure to comply with the Safe Harbor Privacy Principles.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Sanctions must be sufficiently rigorous to ensure compliance by the organization. Organizations that fail
label: BODY

text: to provide annual self-certification letters reaffirming their commitment to the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: Framework and/or the U.S.-EU Safe Harbor Framework will no longer be assured of the relevant Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor benefits and may ultimately be removed from the list of participants maintained on the Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor website.
label: BODY

text: The Department of Commerce has issued a set of frequently asked questions and answers (FAQs) that
label: BODY

text: clarify and supplement the Safe Harbor Privacy Principles.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Helpful Hints on Self-Certifying Compliance
label: HH3

text: This section contains helpful hints on self-certifying compliance with the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: Framework and serves as a checklist that should be reviewed to evaluate an organization’s readiness to
label: BODY

text: self-certify. Although this section provides succinct answers to many common questions regarding the
label: BODY

text: self-certification process, this resource should be used in conjunction with the rest of the Guide, including
label: BODY

text: the requirements for self-certification detailed in FAQ 6.
label: BODY

text: The topics covered below include: determining whether your organization is subject to the jurisdiction of
label: BODY

text: an appropriate statutory authority, developing a Safe Harbor compliant privacy policy statement,
label: BODY

text: establishing a suitable independent recourse mechanism, ensuring that a suitable verification method is
label: BODY

text: in place, and designating a contact within your organization regarding Safe Harbor.
label: BODY

text: Confirm that Your Organization is Subject to the Jurisdiction of the U.S. Federal Trade
label: BODY

text: Commission or the U.S. Department of Transportation: Any U.S. organization that is subject to the
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction of the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) or U.S. air carriers and ticket agents subject to the
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction of the Department of Transportation (DoT) may participate in the Safe Harbor. The FTC and
label: BODY

text: DoT have both stated in letters to the Swiss Federal Data Protection and Information Commissioner
label: BODY

text: (FDPIC) (located with the Framework documents under Letters G and H) that they will take enforcement
label: BODY

text: action against organizations that state that they are in compliance with the Framework, but then fail to live
label: BODY

text: up to their statements. If you are uncertain as to whether your organization falls under the jurisdiction of
label: BODY

text: either the FTC or DoT, then please be sure to contact those agencies for more information.
label: BODY

text: Develop a Safe Harbor Compliant Privacy Policy Statement: Remember to develop a Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: compliant privacy policy before submitting a self-certification form to the Department of Commerce.
label: BODY

text: Make Sure that Your Privacy Policy Conforms to the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Privacy
label: BODY

text: Principles: In order for a privacy policy to be compliant with the Framework, the privacy policy
label: BODY

text: must conform to the seven Safe Harbor Privacy Principles, as well as any relevant points covered
label: BODY

text: in the Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs), which are located with the other Framework
label: BODY

text: documents. In addition, the privacy policy should reflect your organization’s actual and anticipated
label: BODY

text: information handling practices. It is also important to write a policy that is clear, concise, and easy
label: BODY

text: to understand.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Make Specific Reference in the Text of Your Privacy Policy to Your Organization's Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor Compliance: FAQ 6 requires each organization that self-certifies to state in its applicable
label: BODY

text: published privacy policy that it complies with the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework and that it
label: BODY

text: has certified its adherence to the Safe Harbor Privacy Principles. In addition, each organization
label: BODY

text: should include either a hyperlink to the Safe Harbor website or the corresponding URL (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: http://export.gov/safeharbor).
label: BODY

text: Provide an Accurate Privacy Policy Location and Make Sure that Your Privacy Policy is
label: BODY

text: Available to the Public: At the time of self-certification, each organization must provide an
label: BODY

text: accurate location for its applicable privacy policy. In addition, each organization should verify that
label: BODY

text: its privacy policy is effective prior to self-certification. If your organization decides to post your
label: BODY

text: privacy policy on an Internet or Intranet site, it must provide an accurate URL.
label: BODY

text: If your organization: 1) has a public website on which it has posted a general privacy
label: BODY

text: policy statement or made any other representation regarding its privacy practices; and 2)
label: BODY

text: has chosen to cover personal data (e.g., client or customer data) other than your
label: BODY

text: organization’s own human resources data under its self-certification, then the posted
label: BODY

text: privacy-related language must include an affirmative statement that your organization
label: BODY

text: complies with the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework and has certified its adherence to
label: BODY

text: the Safe Harbor Privacy Principles (i.e., it is not sufficient to simply upload a privacy
label: BODY

text: policy to your organization’s Safe Harbor submission). In addition, the posted privacy-
label: BODY

text: related language must also include either a hyperlink to the Safe Harbor website or the
label: BODY

text: corresponding URL (e.g., http://export.gov/safeharbor/).
label: BODY

text: If the information covered by your organization’s self-certification exclusively relates to
label: BODY

text: your own organization’s human resources data, then the privacy policy covering such
label: BODY

text: data need only be made available to your organization’s employees and as part of the
label: BODY

text: Safe Harbor review process (i.e., your organization is not required to upload a copy to
label: BODY

text: your organization’s Safe Harbor submission, but it is encouraged do so). If such a policy
label: BODY

text: is listed as being located at corporate headquarters or on the corporate Intranet or is
label: BODY

text: otherwise inaccessible to the general public via your organization’s public website, then
label: BODY

text: your organization must provide the Department of Commerce with a copy of the policy so
label: BODY

text: that it can be reviewed. If a copy of such a policy is provided for the reason just
label: BODY

text: described, your organization must clarify whether or not it would object to having the copy
label: BODY

text: uploaded to your organization’s Safe Harbor submission.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Establish Your Organization's Independent Recourse Mechanism: Under the Framework’s
label: BODY

text: Enforcement Principle, organizations self-certifying must establish an independent recourse mechanism
label: BODY

text: available to investigate unresolved complaints. (See FAQ 11 for more information regarding dispute
label: BODY

text: resolution under Safe Harbor). The organization must ensure that its recourse mechanism is in place prior
label: BODY

text: to self-certification. In addition, each organization should include in its privacy policy an appropriate
label: BODY

text: reference to the independent recourse mechanism(s), as well as relevant contact information for said
label: BODY

text: mechanism(s).
label: BODY

text: In most cases, organizations self-certifying to Safe Harbor may choose to utilize private sector dispute
label: BODY

text: resolution programs. While programs vary, organizations like the Council of Better Business Bureaus
label: BODY

text: (BBB), TRUSTe, Direct Marketing Association (DMA), the Entertainment Software Rating Board (ESRB),
label: BODY

text: the American Arbitration Association (AAA), and JAMS have developed programs that assist in
label: BODY

text: compliance with the Framework's Enforcement Principle and FAQ 11.
label: BODY

text: Alternatively, organizations may choose to cooperate and comply with the Swiss Federal Data Protection
label: BODY

text: and Information Commissioner (FDPIC). In doing so, an organization must follow the procedures outlined
label: BODY

text: in FAQ 5.
label: BODY

text: If organization human resources data (i.e. personal information about your organization's own
label: BODY

text: employees, past or present, collected in the context of the employment relationship) is being covered in
label: BODY

text: your organization's self-certification, your organization must comply with the FADP with respect to such
label: BODY

text: data. Additional guidance on the handling of human resources data under the Framework is provided in
label: BODY

text: FAQ 9.
label: BODY

text: Ensure that Your Organization's Verification Mechanism is in Place: As discussed in FAQ 7,
label: BODY

text: organizations self-certifying to the Framework are required to have procedures in place for verifying
label: BODY

text: compliance. To meet this requirement, an organization may use either a self-assessment or a third-party
label: BODY

text: assessment program. For additional guidance on the Framework's verification requirement, please see
label: BODY

text: FAQ 7.
label: BODY

text: Designate a Contact within Your Organization Regarding Safe Harbor: Each organization is required
label: BODY

text: to provide a contact for the handling of questions, complaints, access requests, and any other issues
label: BODY

text: arising under the Safe Harbor. This contact can be either the corporate officer that is certifying your
label: BODY

text: organization's compliance with the Framework, or another official within your organization, such as a
label: BODY

text: Chief Privacy Officer.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Safe Harbor Privacy Principles
label: HH3

text: U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Privacy Principles
label: BODY

text: Issued by the U.S. Department of Commerce on February 16, 2009
label: BODY

text: The privacy legislation of Switzerland (Federal Act on Data Protection, FADP) was adopted by the Swiss
label: BODY

text: Parliament on June 19, 1992.1 It requires that transfers of personal data take place only to third countries
label: BODY

text: that provide an “adequate” level of privacy protection (Art. 6 FADP). While the United States and
label: BODY

text: Switzerland share the goal of enhancing privacy protection for their citizens, the United States takes a
label: BODY

text: different approach to privacy from that taken by Switzerland. The United States uses a sectoral approach
label: BODY

text: that relies on a mix of legislation, regulation, and self regulation. Given those differences, many U.S.
label: BODY

text: organizations have expressed uncertainty about the impact of the required “adequacy standard” on
label: BODY

text: personal data transfers from Switzerland to the United States.
label: BODY

text: To diminish this uncertainty and provide a more predictable framework for such data transfers, the
label: BODY

text: Department of Commerce is issuing this document and Frequently Asked Questions (“the Principles”)
label: BODY

text: under its statutory authority to foster, promote, and develop international commerce. As the Swiss and EU
label: BODY

text: legislation on data protection may be considered equivalent, the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Principles and
label: BODY

text: FAQs are modeled on the Principles and FAQs developed for the U.S.-EU Safe Harbor. They are
label: BODY

text: intended for use by U.S. organizations receiving personal data from Switzerland for the purpose of
label: BODY

text: qualifying for the Safe Harbor and the presumption of “adequacy” it creates. Because the Principles were
label: BODY

text: solely designed to serve this specific purpose, their adoption for other purposes may be inappropriate.
label: BODY

text: Decisions by organizations to qualify for the Safe Harbor are entirely voluntary, and organizations may
label: BODY

text: qualify for the Safe Harbor in different ways. Organizations that decide to adhere to the Principles must
label: BODY

text: comply with the Principles in order to obtain and retain the benefits of the Safe Harbor and publicly
label: BODY

text: declare that they do so. For example, if an organization joins a self-regulatory privacy program that
label: BODY

text: adheres to the Principles, it qualifies for the Safe Harbor. Organizations may also qualify by developing
label: BODY

text: their own self-regulatory privacy policies provided that they conform with the Principles.
label: BODY

text: 1 The FADP entered into force on 7/1/1993
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Where in complying with the Principles, an organization relies in whole or in part on self-regulation, its
label: BODY

text: failure to comply with such self-regulation must also be actionable under Section 5 of the Federal Trade
label: BODY

text: Commission Act prohibiting unfair and deceptive acts or another law or regulation prohibiting such acts.
label: BODY

text: (See the annex for the list of U.S. statutory bodies recognized by Switzerland.) In addition, organizations
label: BODY

text: subject to a statutory, regulatory, administrative or other body of law (or of rules) that effectively protects
label: BODY

text: personal privacy may also qualify for Safe Harbor benefits. In all instances, Safe Harbor benefits are
label: BODY

text: assured from the date on which each organization wishing to qualify for the Safe Harbor self-certifies to
label: BODY

text: the Department of Commerce (or its designee) its adherence to the Principles in accordance with the
label: BODY

text: guidance set forth in the Frequently Asked Question on Self-Certification.
label: BODY

text: Adherence to these Principles may be limited: (a) to the extent necessary to meet national security, public
label: BODY

text: interest, or law enforcement requirements; (b) by statute, government regulation, or case law that creates
label: BODY

text: conflicting obligations or explicit authorizations, provided that, in exercising any such authorization, an
label: BODY

text: organization can demonstrate that its non-compliance with the Principles is limited to the extent
label: BODY

text: necessary to meet the overriding legitimate interests furthered by such authorization; or (c) if the effect of
label: BODY

text: Swiss or cantonal data protection measures is to allow exceptions or derogations, provided they are
label: BODY

text: applied in comparable contexts. Consistent with the goal of enhancing privacy protection, organizations
label: BODY

text: should strive to implement these Principles fully and transparently, including indicating in their privacy
label: BODY

text: policies where exceptions to the Principles permitted by (b) above will apply on a regular basis. For the
label: BODY

text: same reason, where the option is allowable under the Principles and/or U.S. law, organizations are
label: BODY

text: expected to opt for the higher protection where possible.
label: BODY

text: Organizations may wish for practical or other reasons to apply the Principles to all their data processing
label: BODY

text: operations, but they are only obligated to apply them to data transferred after they enter the Safe Harbor.
label: BODY

text: To qualify for the Safe Harbor, organizations are not obligated to apply these Principles to personal
label: BODY

text: information in manually processed filing systems. Organizations wishing to benefit from the Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: for receiving information in manually processed filing systems from Switzerland must apply the Principles
label: BODY

text: to any such information transferred after they enter the Safe Harbor. An organization that wishes to
label: BODY

text: extend Safe Harbor benefits to human resources personal information transferred from Switzerland for
label: BODY

text: use in the context of an employment relationship must indicate this when it self-certifies to the
label: BODY

text: Department of Commerce (or its designee) and conform to the requirements set forth in the Frequently
label: BODY

text: Asked Question on Self-Certification.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Organizations will also be able to provide the safeguards necessary under Article 6(2) FADP if they
label: BODY

text: include the Principles in written agreements with parties transferring data from Switzerland for the
label: BODY

text: substantive privacy provisions, once the other provisions for such model contracts are authorized by the
label: BODY

text: Federal Data Protection and Information Commissioner (hereafter “the Commissioner”).
label: BODY

text: U.S. law will apply to questions of interpretation and compliance with the Safe Harbor Principles
label: BODY

text: (including the Frequently Asked Questions) and relevant privacy policies by Safe Harbor organizations,
label: BODY

text: except where organizations have committed to cooperate with the Commissioner. Unless otherwise
label: BODY

text: stated, all provisions of the Safe Harbor Principles and Frequently Asked Questions apply where they are
label: BODY

text: relevant.
label: BODY

text: “Personal data” and “personal information” are data about an identified or identifiable individual that are
label: BODY

text: within the scope of the FADP, received by a U.S. organization from Switzerland, and recorded in any
label: BODY

text: form.
label: BODY

text: Notice: An organization must inform individuals about the purposes for which it collects and uses
label: BODY

text: information about them, how to contact the organization with any inquiries or complaints, the types of third
label: BODY

text: parties to which it discloses the information, and the choices and means the organization offers
label: BODY

text: individuals for limiting its use and disclosure. This notice must be provided in clear and conspicuous
label: BODY

text: language when individuals are first asked to provide personal information to the organization or as soon
label: BODY

text: thereafter as is practicable, but in any event before the organization uses such information for a purpose
label: BODY

text: other than that for which it was originally collected or processed by the transferring organization or
label: BODY

text: discloses it for the first time to a third party.
label: BODY

text: In observing the Notice Principle, organizations should take note of Article 4(3) FADP, which provides,
label: BODY

text: “Personal data may only be processed for the purpose indicated at the time of collection, that is evident
label: BODY

text: from the circumstances, or that is provided by law.”
label: BODY

text: It is not necessary to provide notice when disclosure is made to a third party that is acting as an agent to
label: BODY

text: perform task(s) on behalf of and under the instructions of the organization (Art. 10a FADP). The Onward
label: BODY

text: Transfer Principle, on the other hand, does apply to such disclosures.
label: BODY

text: Choice: An organization must offer individuals the opportunity to choose (opt out) whether their personal
label: BODY

text: information is (a) to be disclosed to a third party or (b) to be used for a purpose that is incompatible with
label: BODY

text: the purpose(s) for which it was originally collected or subsequently authorized by the individual.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Individuals must be provided with clear and conspicuous, readily available, and affordable mechanisms to
label: BODY

text: exercise choice.
label: BODY

text: For sensitive information (i.e., personal information specifying medical or health conditions, personal
label: BODY

text: sexuality, racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious, ideological or trade union-related views or
label: BODY

text: activities, or information on social security measures or administrative or criminal proceedings and
label: BODY

text: sanctions, which are treated outside pending proceedings), they must be given affirmative or explicit (opt
label: BODY

text: in) choice if the information is to be disclosed to a third party or used for a purpose other than those for
label: BODY

text: which it was originally collected or subsequently authorized by the individual through the exercise of opt in
label: BODY

text: choice (Art. 4(5) FADP). In any case, an organization should treat as sensitive any information received
label: BODY

text: from a third party where the third party identifies and treats it as sensitive.
label: BODY

text: In observing the Choice Principle, organizations should take note of Article 4(3) FADP, which provides,
label: BODY

text: “Personal data may only be processed for the purpose indicated at the time of collection, that is evident
label: BODY

text: from the circumstances, or that is provided by law.”
label: BODY

text: It is not necessary to provide choice when disclosure is made to a third party that is acting as an agent to
label: BODY

text: perform task(s) on behalf of and under the instructions of the organization (Art. 10a FADP). The Onward
label: BODY

text: Transfer Principle, on the other hand, does apply to such disclosures.
label: BODY

text: Onward Transfer: To disclose information to a third party, organizations must apply the Notice and
label: BODY

text: Choice Principles. Where an organization wishes to transfer information to a third party that is acting as
label: BODY

text: an agent, as described in the footnotes, it may do so if it first either ascertains that the third party
label: BODY

text: subscribes to the Principles or is subject to the FADP or another adequacy finding or enters into a written
label: BODY

text: agreement with such third party requiring that the third party provide at least the same level of privacy
label: BODY

text: protection as is required by the relevant Principles. If the organization complies with these requirements,
label: BODY

text: it shall not be held responsible (unless the organization agrees otherwise) when a third party to which it
label: BODY

text: transfers such information processes it in a way contrary to any restrictions or representations, unless the
label: BODY

text: organization knew or should have known the third party would process it in such a contrary way and the
label: BODY

text: organization has not taken reasonable steps to prevent or stop such processing.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Security: Organizations creating, maintaining, using or disseminating personal information must take
label: BODY

text: reasonable precautions to protect it from loss, misuse and unauthorized access, disclosure, alteration and
label: BODY

text: destruction.
label: BODY

text: Data Integrity: Consistent with the Principles, personal information must be relevant for the purposes for
label: BODY

text: which it is to be used. An organization may not process personal information in a way that is incompatible
label: BODY

text: with the purposes for which it has been collected or subsequently authorized by the individual. To the
label: BODY

text: extent necessary for those purposes, an organization should take reasonable steps to ensure that data is
label: BODY

text: reliable for its intended use, accurate, complete, and current.
label: BODY

text: Access: Individuals must have access to personal information about them that an organization holds and
label: BODY

text: be able to correct, amend, or delete that information where it is inaccurate, except where the burden or
label: BODY

text: expense of providing access would be disproportionate to the risks to the individual’s privacy in the case
label: BODY

text: in question, or where the rights of persons other than the individual would be violated.
label: BODY

text: Enforcement: Effective privacy protection must include mechanisms for assuring compliance with the
label: BODY

text: Principles, recourse for individuals to whom the data relate affected by non-compliance with the
label: BODY

text: Principles, and consequences for the organization when the Principles are not followed. At a minimum,
label: BODY

text: such mechanisms must include:
label: BODY

text: a) readily available and affordable independent recourse mechanisms by which each individual’s
label: BODY

text: complaints and disputes are investigated and resolved by reference to the Principles and
label: BODY

text: damages awarded where the applicable law or private sector initiatives so provide;
label: BODY

text: b) follow up procedures for verifying that the attestations and assertions businesses make about
label: BODY

text: their privacy practices are true and that privacy practices have been implemented as presented;
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: c) obligations to remedy problems arising out of failure to comply with the Principles by
label: BODY

text: organizations announcing their adherence to them and consequences for such organizations.
label: BODY

text: Sanctions must be sufficiently rigorous to ensure compliance by organizations.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: third parties; and topics including the certification process, liabilities and enforcement, sector-specific
label: BODY

text: rules and exceptions, and potential “what ifs” in the Safe Harbor context.
