text: I. Sensitive Data
label: H4

text: Q: Must an organization always provide explicit (opt in) choice with respect to sensitive data?
label: BODY

text: A: No, such choice is not required where the processing is: (1) in the vital interests of the data subject or
label: BODY

text: another person; (2) necessary for the establishment of legal claims or defenses; (3) required to provide
label: BODY

text: medical care or diagnosis; (4) carried out in the course of legitimate activities by a foundation, association
label: BODY

text: or any other non-profit body with a political, philosophical, religious or trade-union aim and on condition
label: BODY

text: that the processing relates solely to the members of the body or to the persons who have regular contact
label: BODY

text: with it in connection with its purposes and that the data are not disclosed to a third party without the
label: BODY

text: consent of the data subjects; (5) necessary to carry out the organization’s obligations in the field of
label: BODY

text: employment law; or (6) related to data that are manifestly made public by the individual.
label: BODY

text: II. Journalistic Exceptions
label: HH1

text: Q: Given U.S. constitutional protections for freedom of the press and the FADP’s exemption for
label: BODY

text: journalistic material, do the Safe Harbor Principles apply to personal information gathered, maintained or
label: BODY

text: disseminated for journalistic purposes?
label: BODY

text: A: Where the rights of a free press embodied in the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution intersect
label: BODY

text: with privacy protection interests, the First Amendment must govern the balancing of these interests with
label: BODY

text: regard to the activities of U.S. persons or organizations. Personal information that is gathered for
label: BODY

text: publication, broadcast, or other forms of public communication of journalistic material, whether used or
label: BODY

text: not, as well as information found in previously published material disseminated from media archives, is
label: BODY

text: not subject to the requirements of the Safe Harbor Principles.
label: BODY

text: III. Secondary Liability
label: HH1

text: Q: Are Internet service providers (ISPs), telecommunications carriers or other organizations liable under
label: BODY

text: the Safe Harbor Principles when on behalf of another organization they merely transmit, route, switch or
label: BODY

text: cache information that may violate their terms?
label: BODY

text: A: No, as is the case with the FADP itself, the Safe Harbor does not create secondary liability.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: To the extent that an organization is acting as a mere conduit for data transmitted by third parties and
label: BODY

text: does not determine the purposes and means of processing those personal data, it would not be liable.
label: BODY

text: IV. Investment Banking and Audits
label: HH1

text: Q: The activities of auditors and investment bankers may involve processing personal data without the
label: BODY

text: consent or knowledge of the individual. Under what circumstances is this permitted by the Notice, Choice,
label: BODY

text: and Access Principles?
label: BODY

text: A: Investment bankers or auditors may process information without knowledge of the individual only to the
label: BODY

text: extent and for the period necessary to meet statutory or public interest requirements and in other
label: BODY

text: circumstances in which the application of these Principles would prejudice the legitimate interests of the
label: BODY

text: organization. These legitimate interests include the monitoring of companies’ compliance with their legal
label: BODY

text: obligations and legitimate accounting activities, and the need for confidentiality connected with possible
label: BODY

text: acquisitions, mergers, joint ventures, or other similar transactions carried out by investment bankers or
label: BODY

text: auditors.
label: BODY

text: V. The Role of the Commissioner
label: HH1

text: Q: How will companies that commit to cooperate with the Federal Data Protection and Information
label: BODY

text: Commissioner of Switzerland (the Commissioner) make those commitments and how will they be
label: BODY

text: implemented?
label: BODY

text: A: Under the Safe Harbor, U.S. organizations receiving personal data from Switzerland must commit to
label: BODY

text: employ effective mechanisms for assuring compliance with the Safe Harbor Principles. They must
label: BODY

text: provide, as specified in the Enforcement Principle: (a) recourse for individuals to whom the data relate; (b)
label: BODY

text: follow-up procedures for verifying that the attestations and assertions they have made about their privacy
label: BODY

text: practices are true; and (c) obligations to remedy problems arising out of failure to comply with the
label: BODY

text: Principles and consequences for such organizations. An organization may satisfy points (a) and (c) of the
label: BODY

text: Enforcement Principle if it adheres to the requirements of this FAQ for cooperating with the
label: BODY

text: Commissioner.
label: BODY

text: An organization may commit to cooperate with the Commissioner by declaring in its Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: certification to the Department of Commerce (see FAQ 6: Self-Certification) that the organization:
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Elects to satisfy the requirement in points (a) and (c) of the Safe Harbor Enforcement Principle by
label: BODY

text: committing to cooperate with the Commissioner;
label: BODY

text: Will cooperate with the Commissioner in the investigation and resolution of complaints brought
label: BODY

text: under the Safe Harbor; and
label: BODY

text: Will comply with any advice given by the Commissioner where the Commissioner takes the view
label: BODY

text: that the organization needs to take specific action to comply with the Safe Harbor Principles,
label: BODY

text: including remedial or compensatory measures for the benefit of individuals affected by any non-
label: BODY

text: compliance with the Principles, and will provide the Commissioner with written confirmation that
label: BODY

text: such action has been taken.
label: BODY

text: The cooperation of the Commissioner will be provided in the form of information and advice in the
label: BODY

text: following way:
label: BODY

text: The advice of the Commissioner can be delivered directly.
label: BODY

text: The Commissioner will provide advice to the U.S. organizations concerned on unresolved
label: BODY

text: complaints from individuals about the handling of personal information that has been transferred
label: BODY

text: under the Safe Harbor. This advice will be designed to ensure that the Safe Harbor Principles are
label: BODY

text: being correctly applied and will include any remedies for the individual(s) concerned that the
label: BODY

text: Commissioner considers appropriate.
label: BODY

text: The Commissioner will provide such advice in response to referrals from the organizations
label: BODY

text: concerned and/or to complaints received directly from individuals against organizations which
label: BODY

text: have committed to cooperate with the Commissioner for Safe Harbor purposes, while
label: BODY

text: encouraging and if necessary helping such individuals in the first instance to use the in-house
label: BODY

text: complaint handling arrangements that the organization may offer.
label: BODY

text: Advice will be issued only after both sides have had a reasonable opportunity to comment and to
label: BODY

text: provide any evidence they wish. The Commissioner will seek to deliver advice as quickly as this
label: BODY

text: requirement for due process allows.
label: BODY

text: The Commissioner will make public the results of its consideration of complaints submitted to it, if
label: BODY

text: it sees fit.
label: BODY

text: The delivery of advice through the Commissioner will not give rise to any liability for the
label: BODY

text: Commissioner.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: As noted above, organizations choosing this option must undertake to comply with the advice of the
label: BODY

text: Commissioner. If an organization fails to comply with this advice and has offered no satisfactory
label: BODY

text: explanation for its noncompliance, the Commissioner will give notice of its intention either to submit the
label: BODY

text: matter to the Federal Trade Commission or other U.S. federal or state body with statutory powers to take
label: BODY

text: enforcement action in cases of deception or misrepresentation, or to conclude that the agreement to
label: BODY

text: cooperate has been seriously breached and must therefore be considered null and void. In the latter
label: BODY

text: case, the Commissioner will inform the Department of Commerce (or its designee) so that the list of Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor participants can be duly amended. Any failure to fulfill the undertaking to cooperate with the
label: BODY

text: Commissioner, as well as failures to comply with the Safe Harbor Principles, will be actionable as a
label: BODY

text: deceptive practice under Section 5 of the FTC Act or other similar statute.
label: BODY

text: VI. Self-Certification
label: HH1

text: Q: How does an organization self-certify that it adheres to the Safe Harbor Principles?
label: BODY

text: A: Safe Harbor benefits are assured from the date on which an organization self-certifies to the
label: BODY

text: Department of Commerce (or its designee) its adherence to the Principles in accordance with the
label: BODY

text: guidance set forth below.
label: BODY

text: To self-certify for the Safe Harbor, organizations can provide to the Department of Commerce (or its
label: BODY

text: designee) a letter – signed by a corporate officer on behalf of the organization that is joining the Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor – that contains at least the following information:
label: BODY

text: Name of the organization, mailing address, e-mail address, telephone and fax numbers;
label: BODY

text: Description of the activities of the organization with respect to personal information received from
label: BODY

text: Switzerland; and
label: BODY

text: Description of the organization’s privacy policy for such personal information, including:
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: where the privacy policy is available for viewing by the public,
label: BODY

text: its effective date of implementation,
label: BODY

text: a contact office for the handling of complaints, access requests, and any other issues
label: BODY

text: arising under the Safe Harbor,
label: BODY

text: the specific statutory body that has jurisdiction to hear any claims against the
label: BODY

text: organization regarding possible unfair or deceptive practices and violations of laws or
label: BODY

text: regulations governing privacy (and that is listed in the annex to the Principles),
label: BODY

text: the name of any privacy programs in which the organization is a member,
label: BODY

text: the method of verification (e.g., in-house, third party) (see FAQ 7: Verification), and
label: BODY

text: the independent recourse mechanism that is available to investigate unresolved
label: BODY

text: complaints.
label: BODY

text: Where the organization wishes its Safe Harbor benefits to cover human resources information transferred
label: BODY

text: from Switzerland for use in the context of the employment relationship, it may do so where there is a
label: BODY

text: statutory body with jurisdiction to hear claims against the organization arising out of human resources
label: BODY

text: information that is listed in the annex to the Principles. In addition, the organization must indicate this in
label: BODY

text: its letter and declare its commitment to cooperate with the Commissioner or authorities concerned in
label: BODY

text: conformity with FAQ 9: Human Resources and FAQ 5: the Role of the Commissioner as applicable and
label: BODY

text: that it will comply with the advice given by such authorities.
label: BODY

text: The Department (or its designee) will maintain a list of all organizations that file such letters, thereby
label: BODY

text: assuring the availability of Safe Harbor benefits, and will update such list on the basis of annual letters
label: BODY

text: and notifications received pursuant to FAQ 11: Dispute Resolution and Enforcement. Such self-
label: BODY

text: certification letters should be provided not less than annually. Otherwise the organization will be removed
label: BODY

text: from the list and Safe Harbor benefits will no longer be assured. Both the list and the self-certification
label: BODY

text: letters submitted by the organizations will be made publicly available. All organizations that self-certify for
label: BODY

text: the Safe Harbor must also state in their relevant published privacy policy statements that they adhere to
label: BODY

text: the Safe Harbor Principles.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: The undertaking to adhere to the Safe Harbor Principles is not time-limited in respect of data received
label: BODY

text: during the period in which the organization enjoys the benefits of the Safe Harbor. Its undertaking means
label: BODY

text: that it will continue to apply the Principles to such data for as long as the organization stores, uses or
label: BODY

text: discloses them, even if it subsequently leaves the Safe Harbor for any reason.
label: BODY

text: An organization that will cease to exist as a separate legal entity as a result of a merger or a takeover
label: BODY

text: must notify the Department of Commerce (or its designee) of this in advance. The notification should also
label: BODY

text: indicate whether the acquiring entity or the entity resulting from the merger will: (1) continue to be bound
label: BODY

text: by the Safe Harbor Principles by the operation of law governing the takeover or merger or (2) elect to self-
label: BODY

text: certify its adherence to the Safe Harbor Principles or put in place other safeguards, such as a written
label: BODY

text: agreement that will ensure adherence to the Safe Harbor Principles. Where neither (1) nor (2) apply, any
label: BODY

text: data that has been acquired under the Safe Harbor must be promptly deleted.
label: BODY

text: An organization does not need to subject all personal information to the Safe Harbor Principles, but it
label: BODY

text: must subject to the Safe Harbor Principles all personal data received from Switzerland after it joins the
label: BODY

text: Safe Harbor.
label: BODY

text: Any misrepresentation to the general public concerning an organization’s adherence to the Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: Principles may be actionable by the Federal Trade Commission or other relevant government body.
label: BODY

text: Misrepresentations to the Department of Commerce (or its designee) may be actionable under the False
label: BODY

text: Statements Act (18 U.S.C. § 1001).
label: BODY

text: VII. Verification
label: HH1

text: Q:  How do organizations provide follow up procedures for verifying that the attestations and assertions
label: BODY

text: they make about their Safe Harbor privacy practices are true and those privacy practices have been
label: BODY

text: implemented as represented and in accordance with the Safe Harbor Principles?
label: BODY

text: A: To meet the verification requirements of the Enforcement Principle, an organization may verify such
label: BODY

text: attestations and assertions either through self-assessment or outside compliance reviews.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Under the self-assessment approach, such verification would have to indicate that an organization’s
label: BODY

text: published privacy policy regarding personal information received from Switzerland is accurate,
label: BODY

text: comprehensive, prominently displayed, completely implemented and accessible. It would also need to
label: BODY

text: indicate that its privacy policy conforms to the Safe Harbor Principles; that individuals are informed of any
label: BODY

text: in-house arrangements for handling complaints and of the independent mechanisms through which they
label: BODY

text: may pursue complaints; that it has in place procedures for training employees in its implementation, and
label: BODY

text: disciplining them for failure to follow it; and that it has in place internal procedures for periodically
label: BODY

text: conducting objective reviews of compliance with the above. A statement verifying the self-assessment
label: BODY

text: should be signed by a corporate officer or other authorized representative of the organization at least
label: BODY

text: once a year and made available upon request by individuals or in the context of an investigation or a
label: BODY

text: complaint about non-compliance.
label: BODY

text: Organizations should retain their records on the implementation of their Safe Harbor privacy practices
label: BODY

text: and make them available upon request in the context of an investigation or a complaint about non-
label: BODY

text: compliance to the independent body responsible for investigating complaints or to the agency with unfair
label: BODY

text: and deceptive practices jurisdiction.
label: BODY

text: Where the organization has chosen outside compliance review, such a review needs to demonstrate that
label: BODY

text: its privacy policy regarding personal information received from Switzerland conforms to the Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: Principles, it is being complied with, and individuals are informed of the mechanisms through which they
label: BODY

text: may pursue complaints. The methods of review may include without limitation, auditing, random reviews,
label: BODY

text: use of “decoys”, or use of technology tools as appropriate. A statement verifying that an outside
label: BODY

text: compliance review has been successfully completed should be signed either by the reviewer or by the
label: BODY

text: corporate officer or other authorized representative of the organization at least once a year and made
label: BODY

text: available upon request by individuals or in the context of an investigation or a complaint about
label: BODY

text: compliance.
label: BODY

text: VIII. Access
label: HH1

text: Access Principle:
label: BODY

text: Individuals must have access to personal information about them that an organization holds and be able
label: BODY

text: to correct, amend or delete that information where it is inaccurate, except where the burden or expense of
label: BODY

text: providing access would be disproportionate to the risks to the individual’s privacy in the case in question,
label: BODY

text: or where the legitimate rights of persons other than the individual would be violated.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Q1: Is the right of access absolute?
label: BODY

text: A1: No, under the Safe Harbor Principles, the right of access is fundamental to privacy protection. In
label: BODY

text: particular, it allows individuals to verify the accuracy of information held about them. Nonetheless, the
label: BODY

text: obligation of an organization to provide access to the personal information it holds about an individual is
label: BODY

text: subject to the principle of proportionality or reasonableness and has to be tempered in certain instances.
label: BODY

text: Indeed, the Explanatory Memorandum to the 1980 OECD Privacy Guidelines makes clear that an
label: BODY

text: organization’s access obligation is not absolute. It does not require the exceedingly thorough search
label: BODY

text: mandated, for example, by a subpoena, nor does it require access to all the different forms in which the
label: BODY

text: information may be maintained by the organization.
label: BODY

text: Rather, experience has shown that in responding to individuals’ access requests, organizations should
label: BODY

text: first be guided by the concern(s) that led to the requests in the first place. For example, if an access
label: BODY

text: request is vague or broad in scope, an organization may engage the individual in a dialogue so as to
label: BODY

text: better understand the motivation for the request and to locate responsive information. The organization
label: BODY

text: might inquire about which part(s) of the organization the individual interacted with and/or about the nature
label: BODY

text: of the information (or its use) that is the subject of the access request. Individuals do not, however, have
label: BODY

text: to justify requests for access to their own data.
label: BODY

text: Expense and burden are important factors and should be taken into account but they are not controlling in
label: BODY

text: determining whether providing access is reasonable. For example, if the information is used for decisions
label: BODY

text: that will significantly affect the individual (e.g., the denial or grant of important benefits, such as insurance,
label: BODY

text: a mortgage, or a job), then consistent with the other provisions of these FAQs, the organization would
label: BODY

text: have to disclose that information even if it is relatively difficult or expensive to provide.
label: BODY

text: If the information requested is not sensitive or not used for decisions that will significantly affect the
label: BODY

text: individual (e.g., non-sensitive marketing data that is used to determine whether or not to send the
label: BODY

text: individual a catalog), but is readily available and inexpensive to provide, an organization would have to
label: BODY

text: provide access to factual information that the organization stores about the individual. The information
label: BODY

text: concerned could include facts obtained from the individual, facts gathered in the course of a transaction,
label: BODY

text: or facts obtained from others that pertain to the individual.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Consistent with the fundamental nature of access, organizations should always make good faith efforts to
label: BODY

text: provide access. For example, where certain information needs to be protected and can be readily
label: BODY

text: separated from other information subject to an access request, the organization should redact the
label: BODY

text: protected information and make available the other information. If an organization determines that access
label: BODY

text: should be denied in any particular instance, it should provide the individual requesting access with an
label: BODY

text: explanation of why it has made that determination and a contact point for any further inquiries.
label: BODY

text: Q2: What is confidential commercial information and may organizations deny access in order to
label: BODY

text: safeguard it?
label: BODY

text: A2: Confidential commercial information (as that term is used in the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure on
label: BODY

text: discovery) is information which an organization has taken steps to protect from disclosure, where
label: BODY

text: disclosure would help a competitor in the market. The particular computer program an organization uses,
label: BODY

text: such as a modeling program, or the details of that program may be confidential commercial information.
label: BODY

text: Where confidential commercial information can be readily separated from other information subject to an
label: BODY

text: access request, the organization should redact the confidential commercial information and make
label: BODY

text: available the non-confidential information. Organizations may deny or limit access to the extent that
label: BODY

text: granting it would reveal its own confidential commercial information as defined above, such as marketing
label: BODY

text: inferences or classifications generated by the organization, or the confidential commercial information of
label: BODY

text: another where such information is subject to a contractual obligation of confidentiality in circumstances
label: BODY

text: where such an obligation of confidentiality would normally be undertaken or imposed.
label: BODY

text: Q3: In providing access, may an organization disclose to individuals personal information about them
label: BODY

text: derived from its data bases or is access to the data base itself required?
label: BODY

text: A3: Access can be provided in the form of disclosure by an organization to the individual and does not
label: BODY

text: require access by the individual to an organization’s data base.
label: BODY

text: Q4: Does an organization have to restructure its data bases to be able to provide access?
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: A4: Access needs to be provided only to the extent that an organization stores the information. The
label: BODY

text: Access Principle does not itself create any obligation to retain, maintain, reorganize, or restructure
label: BODY

text: personal information files.
label: BODY

text: Q5: These replies make clear that access may be denied in certain circumstances. In what other
label: BODY

text: circumstances may an organization deny individuals access to their personal information?
label: BODY

text: A5: Such circumstances are limited, and any reasons for denying access must be specific. An
label: BODY

text: organization can refuse to provide access to information to the extent that disclosure is likely to interfere
label: BODY

text: with the safeguarding of important countervailing public interests, such as national security; defense; or
label: BODY

text: public security. In addition, where personal information is processed solely for research or statistical
label: BODY

text: purposes, access may be denied. Other reasons for denying or limiting access are:
label: BODY

text: Interference with execution or enforcement of the law, including the prevention, investigation or
label: BODY

text: detection of offenses or the right to a fair trial;
label: BODY

text: Interference with private causes of action, including the prevention, investigation or detection of
label: BODY

text: legal claims or the right to a fair trial;
label: BODY

text: Disclosure of personal information pertaining to other individual(s) where such references cannot
label: BODY

text: be redacted;
label: BODY

text: Breaching a legal or other professional privilege or obligation;
label: BODY

text: Breaching the necessary confidentiality of future or ongoing negotiations, such as those involving
label: BODY

text: the acquisition of publicly quoted companies;
label: BODY

text: Prejudicing employee security investigations or grievance proceedings;
label: BODY

text: Prejudicing the confidentiality that may be necessary for limited periods in connection with
label: BODY

text: employee succession planning and corporate re-organizations; or
label: BODY

text: Prejudicing the confidentiality that may be necessary in connection with monitoring, inspection or
label: BODY

text: regulatory functions connected with sound economic or financial management; or
label: BODY

text: Other circumstances in which the burden or cost of providing access would be disproportionate or
label: BODY

text: the legitimate rights or interests of others would be violated.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: An organization which claims an exception has the burden of demonstrating its applicability (as is
label: BODY

text: normally the case). As noted above, the reasons for denying or limiting access and a contact point for
label: BODY

text: further inquiries should be given to individuals.
label: BODY

text: Q6: Can an organization charge a fee to cover the cost of providing access?
label: BODY

text: A6: Yes, the OECD Guidelines recognize that organizations may charge a fee, provided that it is not
label: BODY

text: excessive. Thus organizations may charge a reasonable fee for access. Charging a fee may be useful in
label: BODY

text: discouraging repetitive and vexatious requests.
label: BODY

text: Organizations that are in the business of selling publicly available information may thus charge the
label: BODY

text: organization’s customary fee in responding to requests for access. Individuals may alternatively seek
label: BODY

text: access to their information from the organization that originally compiled the data.
label: BODY

text: Access may not be refused on cost grounds if the individual offers to pay the costs.
label: BODY

text: Q7: Is an organization required to provide access to personal information derived from public records?
label: BODY

text: A7: To clarify first, public records are those records kept by government agencies or entities at any level
label: BODY

text: that are open to consultation by the public in general. It is not necessary to apply the Access Principle to
label: BODY

text: such information as long as it is not combined with other personal information, apart from when small
label: BODY

text: amounts of non-public record information are used for indexing or organizing public record information.
label: BODY

text: However, any conditions for consultation established by the relevant jurisdiction are to be respected.
label: BODY

text: Where public record information is combined with other non-public record information (other than as
label: BODY

text: specifically noted above), however, an organization must provide access to all such information,
label: BODY

text: assuming it is not subject to other permitted exceptions.
label: BODY

text: Q8: Does the Access Principle have to be applied to publicly available personal information?
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: A8: As with public record information (see Q7), it is not necessary to provide access to information that is
label: BODY

text: already publicly available to the public at large, as long as it is not combined with non-publicly available
label: BODY

text: information.
label: BODY

text: Q9: How can an organization protect itself against repetitious or vexatious requests for access?
label: BODY

text: A9: An organization does not have to respond to such requests for access. For these reasons,
label: BODY

text: organizations may charge a reasonable fee and may set reasonable limits on the number of times within
label: BODY

text: a given period that access requests from a particular individual will be met. In setting such limitations, an
label: BODY

text: organization should consider such factors as the frequency with which information is updated, the
label: BODY

text: purpose for which the data are used, and the nature of the information.
label: BODY

text: Q10: How can an organization protect itself against fraudulent requests for access?
label: BODY

text: A10: An organization is not required to provide access unless it is supplied with sufficient information to
label: BODY

text: allow it to confirm the identity of the person making the request.
label: BODY

text: Q11: Is there a time within which responses must be provided to access requests?
label: BODY

text: A11: Yes, organizations should respond without excessive delay and within a reasonable time period.
label: BODY

text: This requirement may be satisfied in different ways as the explanatory memorandum to the 1980 OECD
label: BODY

text: Privacy Guidelines states. For example, a data controller who provides information to data subjects at
label: BODY

text: regular intervals may be exempted from obligations to respond at once to individual requests.
label: BODY

text: IX. Human Resources
label: HH1

text: Q1: Is the transfer from Switzerland to the United States of personal information collected in the context
label: BODY

text: of the employment relationship covered by the Safe Harbor?
label: BODY

text: A1: Yes, where a company in Switzerland transfers personal information about its employees (past or
label: BODY

text: present) collected in the context of the employment relationship, to a parent, affiliate, or unaffiliated
label: BODY

text: service provider in the United States participating in the Safe Harbor, the transfer enjoys the benefits of
label: BODY

text: the Safe Harbor. In such cases, the collection of the information and its processing prior to transfer will
label: BODY

text: have been subject to Swiss data protection laws, and any conditions for or restrictions on its transfer
label: BODY

text: according to those laws will have to be respected.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: The Safe Harbor Principles are relevant only when individually identified or identifiable records are
label: BODY

text: transferred or accessed. Statistical reporting relying on aggregate employment data and/or the use of
label: BODY

text: anonymized or pseudonymized data does not raise privacy concerns.
label: BODY

text: Q2: How do the Notice and Choice Principles apply to such information?
label: BODY

text: A2: A U.S. organization that has received employee information from Switzerland under the Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: may disclose it to third parties and/or use it for different purposes only in accordance with the Notice and
label: BODY

text: Choice Principles. For example, where an organization intends to use personal information collected
label: BODY

text: through the employment relationship for non-employment-related purposes, such as marketing
label: BODY

text: communications, the U.S. organization must provide the affected individuals with choice before doing so,
label: BODY

text: unless they have already authorized the use of the information for such purposes. Moreover, such
label: BODY

text: choices must not be used to restrict employment opportunities or take any punitive action against such
label: BODY

text: employees.
label: BODY

text: In addition, employers should make reasonable efforts to accommodate employee privacy preferences.
label: BODY

text: This could include, for example, restricting access to the data, anonymizing certain data, or assigning
label: BODY

text: codes or pseudonyms when the actual names are not required for the management purpose at hand.
label: BODY

text: To the extent and for the period necessary to avoid prejudicing the legitimate interests of the organization
label: BODY

text: in making promotions, appointments, or other similar employment decisions, an organization does not
label: BODY

text: need to offer notice and choice.
label: BODY

text: Q3: How does the Access Principle apply?
label: BODY

text: A3: The FAQs on access provide guidance on reasons which may justify denying or limiting access on
label: BODY

text: request in the human resources context. Of course, employers in Switzerland must comply with local
label: BODY

text: regulations and ensure that Swiss employees have access to such information as is required by Swiss
label: BODY

text: law, regardless of the location of data processing and storage. The Safe Harbor requires that an
label: BODY

text: organization processing such data in the United States will cooperate in providing such access either
label: BODY

text: directly or through the Swiss employer.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Q4: How will enforcement be handled for employee data under the Safe Harbor Principles?
label: BODY

text: A4: In so far as information is used only in the context of the employment relationship, primary
label: BODY

text: responsibility for the data vis-à-vis the employee remains with the company in Switzerland. It follows that,
label: BODY

text: where Swiss employees make complaints about violations of their data protection rights and are not
label: BODY

text: satisfied with the results of internal review, complaint, and appeal procedures (or any applicable
label: BODY

text: grievance procedures under a contract with a trade union), they should be directed to the Commissioner
label: BODY

text: or labor authority in the jurisdiction where the employee works. This also includes cases where the
label: BODY

text: alleged mishandling of their personal information has taken place in the United States, is the
label: BODY

text: responsibility of the U.S. organization that has received the information from the employer and not of the
label: BODY

text: employer and thus involves an alleged breach of the Safe Harbor Principles, rather than of the FADP.
label: BODY

text: This will be the most efficient way to address the often overlapping rights and obligations imposed by
label: BODY

text: local labor law and labor agreements as well as data protection law.
label: BODY

text: A U.S. organization participating in the Safe Harbor that uses Swiss human resources data transferred
label: BODY

text: from Switzerland in the context of the employment relationship and that wishes such transfers to be
label: BODY

text: covered by the Safe Harbor must therefore commit to cooperate in investigations by and to comply with
label: BODY

text: the advice of the Commissioner in such cases. The Commissioner in this way will notify the Department
label: BODY

text: of Commerce. If a U.S. organization participating in the Safe Harbor wishes to transfer human resources
label: BODY

text: data from Switzerland and the Commissioner has not so agreed, the provisions of FAQ 5: the Role of the
label: BODY

text: Commissioner will apply.
label: BODY

text: X. Data Processing by Third Parties
label: HH1

text: Q: When data is transferred from Switzerland to the United States only for processing purposes, will a
label: BODY

text: contract be required, regardless of participation by the processor in the Safe Harbor?
label: BODY

text: A: Yes, data controllers in Switzerland are always required to enter into a contract when a transfer for
label: BODY

text: mere processing is made, whether the processing operation is carried out inside or outside Switzerland.
label: BODY

text: (Article 10a FADP) The purpose of the contract is to protect the interests of the data controller (i.e. the
label: BODY

text: person or body who determines the purposes and means of processing, who retains full responsibility for
label: BODY

text: the data vis-à-vis the individual(s) concerned). The contract thus specifies the processing to be carried
label: BODY

text: out and any measures necessary to ensure that the data are kept secure.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: A U.S. organization participating in the Safe Harbor and receiving personal information from Switzerland
label: BODY

text: merely for processing thus does not have to apply the Principles to this information, because the
label: BODY

text: controller in Switzerland remains responsible for it vis-à-vis the individual in accordance with the relevant
label: BODY

text: Swiss provisions (which may be more stringent than the equivalent Safe Harbor Principles).
label: BODY

text: Because adequate protection is provided by Safe Harbor participants, contracts with Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: participants for mere processing do not require prior authorization (or such authorization will be granted
label: BODY

text: automatically) as would be required for contracts with recipients not participating in the Safe Harbor or
label: BODY

text: otherwise not providing adequate protection.
label: BODY

text: XI. Dispute Resolution and Enforcement
label: HH1

text: How should the dispute resolution requirements of the Enforcement Principle be implemented, and how
label: BODY

text: will an organization’s persistent failure to comply with the Principles be handled?
label: BODY

text: A: The Enforcement Principle sets out the requirements for Safe Harbor enforcement. How to meet the
label: BODY

text: requirements of point (b) of the Principle is set out in FAQ 7: Verification. This FAQ addresses points (a)2
label: BODY

text: and (c)3, both of which require independent recourse mechanisms. These mechanisms may take different
label: BODY

text: forms, but they must meet the Enforcement Principle’s requirements. Organizations may satisfy the
label: BODY

text: requirements through the following:
label: BODY

text: Compliance with private sector developed privacy programs that incorporate the Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: Principles into their rules and that include effective enforcement mechanisms of the type
label: BODY

text: described in the Enforcement Principle;
label: BODY

text: Compliance with legal or regulatory supervisory authorities that provide for handling of individual
label: BODY

text: complaints and dispute resolution; or
label: BODY

text: Commitment to cooperate with the Commissioner or authorized representatives.
label: BODY

text: 2Section (a) of the Enforcement Principle concerns the obligation to provide “readily available and affordable independent recourse mechanisms
label: BODY

text: by which each individual’s complaints and disputes are investigated and resolved by reference to the Principles and damages awarded where the
label: BODY

text: applicable law or private sector initiatives so provide”
label: BODY

text: 3 Section (c) of the Enforcement Principle concerns the obligation to “remedy problems arising out of failure to comply with the Principles by
label: BODY

text: organizations announcing their adherence to them and consequences for such organizations.”
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: This list is intended to be illustrative and not limiting. The private sector may design other mechanisms to
label: BODY

text: provide enforcement, so long as they meet the requirements of the Enforcement Principle and the FAQs.
label: BODY

text: Please note that the Enforcement Principle’s requirements are additional to the requirements set forth in
label: BODY

text: paragraph 3 of the introduction to the Principles that self-regulatory efforts must be enforceable under
label: BODY

text: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act or similar statute.
label: BODY

text: Recourse Mechanisms:
label: BODY

text: Consumers should be encouraged to raise any complaints they may have with the relevant organization
label: BODY

text: before proceeding to independent recourse mechanisms. Whether a recourse mechanism is independent
label: BODY

text: is a factual question that can be demonstrated in a number of ways, for example, by transparent
label: BODY

text: composition and financing or a proven track record. As required by the Enforcement Principle, the
label: BODY

text: recourse available to individuals must be readily available and affordable. Dispute resolution bodies
label: BODY

text: should look into each complaint received from individuals unless they are obviously unfounded or
label: BODY

text: frivolous. This does not preclude the establishment of eligibility requirements by the organization
label: BODY

text: operating the recourse mechanism, but such requirements should be transparent and justified (for
label: BODY

text: example to exclude complaints that fall outside the scope of the program or are for consideration in
label: BODY

text: another forum), and should not have the effect of undermining the commitment to look into legitimate
label: BODY

text: complaints. In addition, recourse mechanisms should provide individuals with full and readily available
label: BODY

text: information about how the dispute resolution procedure works when they file a complaint. Such
label: BODY

text: information should include notice about the mechanism’s privacy practices, in conformity with the Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor Principles, where dispute resolution bodies are not required to conform with the Enforcement
label: BODY

text: Principle. They may derogate from the Principles where they encounter conflicting obligations or explicit
label: BODY

text: authorizations in the performance of their specific tasks. They should also co-operate in the development
label: BODY

text: of tools such as standard complaint forms to facilitate the complaint resolution process.
label: BODY

text: Remedies and Sanctions:
label: BODY

text: The result of any remedies provided by the dispute resolution body should be that the effects of non-
label: BODY

text: compliance are reversed or corrected by the organization, in so far as feasible, and that future processing
label: BODY

text: by the organization will be in conformity with the Principles and, where appropriate, that processing of the
label: BODY

text: personal data of the individual who has brought the complaint will cease.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Sanctions need to be rigorous enough to ensure compliance by the organization with the Principles. A
label: BODY

text: range of sanctions of varying degrees of severity will allow dispute resolution bodies to respond
label: BODY

text: appropriately to varying degrees of non-compliance. Sanctions should include both publicity for findings of
label: BODY

text: non-compliance and the requirement to delete data in certain circumstances. Dispute resolution bodies
label: BODY

text: have discretion about the circumstances in which they use these sanctions. The sensitivity of the data
label: BODY

text: concerned is one factor to be taken into consideration in deciding whether deletion of data should be
label: BODY

text: required, as is whether an organization has collected, used or disclosed information in blatant
label: BODY

text: contravention of the Principles. Other sanctions could include suspension and removal of a seal,
label: BODY

text: compensation for individuals for losses incurred as a result of non-compliance and injunctive orders.
label: BODY

text: Private sector dispute resolution bodies and self-regulatory bodies must notify failures of Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: organizations to comply with their rulings to the governmental body with applicable jurisdiction or to the
label: BODY

text: courts, as appropriate, and to notify the Department of Commerce (or its designee).
label: BODY

text: FTC Action:
label: BODY

text: The FTC has committed to reviewing on a priority basis referrals received from privacy self-regulatory
label: BODY

text: organizations, such as BBB and TRUSTe, and the Commissioner alleging non-compliance with the Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor Principles to determine whether Section 5 of the FTC Act prohibiting unfair or deceptive acts or
label: BODY

text: practices in commerce has been violated. If the FTC concludes that is has reason(s) to believe Section 5
label: BODY

text: has been violated, it may resolve the matter by seeking an administrative cease and desist order
label: BODY

text: prohibiting the challenged practices or by filing a complaint in a federal district court, which if successful
label: BODY

text: could result in a federal court order to same effect. The FTC may obtain civil penalties for violations of an
label: BODY

text: administrative cease and desist order and may pursue civil or criminal contempt for violation of a federal
label: BODY

text: court order. The FTC will notify the Department of Commerce of any such actions it takes. The
label: BODY

text: Department of Commerce encourages other government bodies to notify it of the final disposition of any
label: BODY

text: such referrals or other rulings determining adherence to the Safe Harbor Principles.
label: BODY

text: Persistent Failure to Comply:
label: BODY

text: If an organization persistently fails to comply with the Principles, it is no longer entitled to benefit from the
label: BODY

text: Safe Harbor. Persistent failure to comply arises where an organization that has self-certified to the
label: BODY

text: Department of Commerce (or its designee) refuses to comply with a final determination by any self-
label: BODY

text: regulatory or government body or where such a body determines that an organization frequently fails to
label: BODY

text: comply with the Principles to the point where its claim to comply is no longer credible. In these cases, the
label: BODY

text: organization must promptly notify the Department of Commerce (or its designee) of such facts. Failure to
label: BODY

text: do so may be actionable under the False Statements Act (18 U.S.C. § 1001).
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: The Department (or its designee) will indicate on the public list it maintains of organizations self-certifying
label: BODY

text: adherence to the Safe Harbor Principles any notification it receives of persistent failure to comply,
label: BODY

text: whether it is received from the organization itself, from a self-regulatory body, or from a government body,
label: BODY

text: but only after first providing thirty (30) days’ notice and an opportunity to respond to the organization that
label: BODY

text: has failed to comply. Accordingly, the public list maintained by the Department of Commerce (or its
label: BODY

text: designee) will make clear which organizations are assured and which organizations are no longer
label: BODY

text: assured of Safe Harbor benefits.
label: BODY

text: An organization applying to participate in a self-regulatory body for the purposes of re-qualifying for the
label: BODY

text: Safe Harbor must provide that body with full information about its prior participation in the Safe Harbor.
label: BODY

text: XII. Choice - Timing of Opt Out
label: HH1

text: Q: Does the Choice Principle permit an individual to exercise choice only at the beginning of a
label: BODY

text: relationship or at any time?
label: BODY

text: A: Generally, the purpose of the Choice Principle is to ensure that personal information is used and
label: BODY

text: disclosed in ways that are consistent with the individual’s expectations and choices. Accordingly, an
label: BODY

text: individual should be able to exercise “opt out” (or choice) of having personal information used for direct
label: BODY

text: marketing at any time subject to reasonable limits established by the organization, such as giving the
label: BODY

text: organization time to make the opt out effective. An organization may also require sufficient information to
label: BODY

text: confirm the identity of the individual requesting the “opt out”. In the United States, individuals may be able
label: BODY

text: to exercise this option through the use of a central “opt out” program such as the Direct Marketing
label: BODY

text: Association’s Mail Preference Service. Organizations that participate in the Direct Marketing Association’s
label: BODY

text: Mail Preference Service should promote its availability to consumers who do not wish to receive
label: BODY

text: commercial information. In any event, an individual should be given a readily available and affordable
label: BODY

text: mechanism to exercise this option.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Similarly, an organization may use information for certain direct marketing purposes when it is
label: BODY

text: impracticable to provide the individual with an opportunity to opt out before using the information, if the
label: BODY

text: organization promptly gives the individual such opportunity at the same time (and upon request at any
label: BODY

text: time) to decline (at no cost to the individual) to receive any further direct marketing communications and
label: BODY

text: the organization complies with the individual’s wishes.
label: BODY

text: XIII. Travel Information
label: HH1

text: Q: When can airline passenger reservation and other travel information, such as frequent flyer or hotel
label: BODY

text: reservation information and special handling needs, such as meals to meet religious requirements or
label: BODY

text: physical assistance, be transferred to organizations located outside Switzerland?
label: BODY

text: A: Such information may be transferred in several different circumstances. Under Article 6(2) FADP,
label: BODY

text: personal data may be transferred to a third country “in the absence of legislation that guarantees
label: BODY

text: adequate protection within the meaning of Article 6(1)” on the condition that:
label: BODY

text: It is necessary to provide the services requested by the consumer or to fulfill the terms of an
label: BODY

text: agreement, such as a “frequent flyer” agreement; or
label: BODY

text: It has been unambiguously consented to by the consumer in the specific case.
label: BODY

text: U.S. organizations subscribing to the Safe Harbor provide adequate protection for personal data and may
label: BODY

text: therefore receive data transfers from Switzerland without meeting those conditions or other conditions set
label: BODY

text: out in Article 6 FADP. Since the Safe Harbor includes specific rules for sensitive information, such
label: BODY

text: information (which may need to be collected, for example, in connection with customers’ needs for
label: BODY

text: physical assistance) may be included in transfers to Safe Harbor participants. In all cases, however, the
label: BODY

text: organization transferring the information has to respect the law in Switzerland, which may inter alia
label: BODY

text: impose special conditions for the handling of sensitive data.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: XIV. Pharmaceutical and Medical Products
label: H4

text: Q1: If personal data are collected in Switzerland and transferred to the United States for pharmaceutical
label: BODY

text: research and/or other purposes, do Swiss laws or the Safe Harbor Principles apply?
label: BODY

text: A1: Swiss law applies to the collection of the personal data and to any processing that takes place prior to
label: BODY

text: the transfer to the United States. The Safe Harbor Principles apply to the data once they have been
label: BODY

text: transferred to the United States. Data used for pharmaceutical research and other purposes should be
label: BODY

text: anonymized when appropriate.
label: BODY

text: Q2: Personal data developed in specific medical or pharmaceutical research studies often play a valuable
label: BODY

text: role in future scientific research. Where personal data collected for one research study are transferred to
label: BODY

text: a U.S. organization in the Safe Harbor, may the organization use the data for a new scientific research
label: BODY

text: activity?
label: BODY

text: A2: Yes, if appropriate notice and choice have been provided in the first instance. Such a notice should
label: BODY

text: provide information about any future specific uses of the data, such as periodic follow-up, related studies,
label: BODY

text: or marketing. It is understood that not all future uses of the data can be specified, since a new research
label: BODY

text: use could arise from new insights on the original data, new medical discoveries and advances, and public
label: BODY

text: health and regulatory developments. Where appropriate, the notice should therefore include an
label: BODY

text: explanation that personal data may be used in future medical and pharmaceutical research activities that
label: BODY

text: are unanticipated. If the use is not consistent with the general research purpose(s) for which the data
label: BODY

text: were originally collected, or to which the individual has consented subsequently, new consent must be
label: BODY

text: obtained.
label: BODY

text: Q3: What happens to an individual’s data if a participant decides voluntarily or at the request of the
label: BODY

text: sponsor to withdraw from the clinical trial?
label: BODY

text: A3: Participants may decide or be asked to withdraw from a clinical trial at any time. Any data collected
label: BODY

text: previous to withdrawal may still be processed along with other data collected as part of the clinical trial;
label: BODY

text: however, if this was made clear to the participant in the notice at the time he or she agreed to participate.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Question 4: Pharmaceutical and medical device companies are allowed to provide personal data from
label: BODY

text: clinical trials conducted in Switzerland to regulators in the United States for regulatory and supervision
label: BODY

text: purposes. Are similar transfers allowed to parties other than regulators, such as company locations and
label: BODY

text: other researchers?
label: BODY

text: A4: Yes, consistent with the Principles of Notice and Choice.
label: BODY

text: Q5: To ensure objectivity in many clinical trials, participants, and often investigators, as well, cannot be
label: BODY

text: given access to information about which treatment each participant may be receiving. Doing so would
label: BODY

text: jeopardize the validity of the research study and results. Will participants in such clinical trials (referred to
label: BODY

text: as “blinded” studies) have access to the data on their treatment during the trial?
label: BODY

text: A5: No, such access does not have to be provided to a participant if this restriction has been explained
label: BODY

text: when the participant entered the trial and the disclosure of such information would jeopardize the integrity
label: BODY

text: of the research effort. Agreement to participate in the trial under these conditions is a reasonable forgoing
label: BODY

text: of the right of access. Following the conclusion of the trial and analysis of the results, participants should
label: BODY

text: have access to their data if they request it. They should seek it primarily from the physician or other
label: BODY

text: health care provider from whom they received treatment within the clinical trial, or secondarily from the
label: BODY

text: sponsoring company.
label: BODY

text: Q6: Does a pharmaceutical or medical device firm have to apply the Safe Harbor Principles with respect
label: BODY

text: to notice, choice, onward transfer, and access in its product safety and efficacy monitoring activities,
label: BODY

text: including the reporting of adverse events and the tracking of patients/subjects using certain medicines or
label: BODY

text: medical devices (e.g., a pacemaker)?
label: BODY

text: A6: No, to the extent that adherence to the Principles interferes with compliance with regulatory
label: BODY

text: requirements. This is true both with respect to reports by, for example, health care providers to
label: BODY

text: pharmaceutical and medical device companies, and with respect to reports by pharmaceutical and
label: BODY

text: medical device companies to government agencies like the Food and Drug Administration.
label: BODY

text: Q7: Invariably, research data are uniquely key-coded at their origin by the principal investigator so as not
label: BODY

text: to reveal the identity of individual data subjects. Pharmaceutical companies sponsoring such research do
label: BODY

text: not receive the key. The unique key code is held only by the researcher, so that he/she can identify the
label: BODY

text: research subject under special circumstances (e.g., if follow-up medical attention is required). Does a
label: BODY

text: transfer from Switzerland to the United States of data coded in this way constitute a transfer of personal
label: BODY

text: data that is subject to the Safe Harbor Principles?
label: BODY

text: A7: No. This would not constitute a transfer of personal data that would be subject to the Principles.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: XV. Public Record and Publicly Available Information
label: H4

text: Q: Is it necessary to apply the Notice, Choice and Onward Transfer Principles to public record information
label: BODY

text: or publicly available information?
label: BODY

text: A: It is not necessary to apply the Notice, Choice or Onward Transfer Principles to public record
label: BODY

text: information, as long as it is not combined with non-public record information and as long as any
label: BODY

text: conditions for consultation established by the relevant jurisdiction are respected.
label: BODY

text: Also, it is generally not necessary to apply the Notice, Choice or Onward Transfer Principles to publicly
label: BODY

text: available information unless the Swiss transferor indicates that such information is subject to restrictions
label: BODY

text: that require application of those Principles by the organization for the uses it intends. Organizations will
label: BODY

text: have no liability for how such information is used by those obtaining such information from published
label: BODY

text: materials.
label: BODY

text: Where an organization is found to have intentionally made personal information public in contravention of
label: BODY

text: the Principles so that it or others may benefit from these exceptions, it will cease to qualify for the benefits
label: BODY

text: of the Safe Harbor.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: XYZ Website Privacy Statement

text: XYZ respects the privacy of visitors to its websites, as a result, we have developed this website privacy
label: BODY

text: policy. This website privacy policy applies only to the operation of websites that directly link to this policy
label: BODY

text: when you click on “privacy statement” in the website footer. Through this website XYZ will collect

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: discussion below about “IP Addresses” if you have a broadband connection). We will use Your
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: services.

text: We may also use Your Information to contact you and/or provide you with general health information (like
label: BODY

text: information on certain health conditions) as well as information about our products and services. We may
label: BODY

text: also enhance or merge Your Information with data obtained from third parties for the same purposes.
label: BODY

text: Any other information transferred by you in connection with your visit to this site (“Other Information” - that
label: BODY

text: is, information that cannot be used to identify you) may be included in databases owned and maintained
label: BODY

text: by XYZ or its agents. XYZ retains all rights to these databases and the information contained in them.
label: BODY

text: Other Information we collect may include your IP Address and other information gathered through our
label: BODY

text: weblogs and cookies (see below).
label: BODY

text: This site may use a technology known as web beacons - sometimes called single-pixel gifs - that allow
label: BODY

text: this site to collect web log information. A web beacon is a graphic on a web page or in an e-mail message
label: BODY

text: designed to track pages viewed or messages opened. Web log information is gathered when you visit
label: BODY

text: one of our websites by the computer that hosts our website (called a “webserver”). The webserver
label: BODY

text: automatically recognizes some non-personal information, such as the date and time you visited our site,
label: BODY

text: the pages you visited, the website you came from, the type of browser you are using (e.g., Internet
label: BODY

text: Explorer), the type of operating system you are using (e.g., Windows 2000), and the domain name and
label: BODY

text: address of your Internet service provider (e.g., AOL). We may also include web beacons in promotional e-
label: BODY

text: mail messages in order to determine whether messages have been opened.
label: BODY

text: This website may use a technology called a “cookie”. A cookie is a piece of information that our
label: BODY

text: webserver sends to your computer (actually to your browser file) when you access a website. Then when
label: BODY

text: you come back our site will detect whether you have one of our cookies on your computer. Our cookies
label: BODY

text: help provide additional functionality to the site and help us analyze site usage more accurately. For
label: BODY

text: instance, our site may set a cookie on your browser that keeps you from needing to remember and then
label: BODY

text: enter a password more than once during a visit to the site.
label: BODY

text: This website uses Internet Protocol (IP) Addresses. An IP Address is a number assigned to your
label: BODY

text: computer by your Internet service provider so you can access the Internet. Generally, an IP address
label: BODY

text: changes each time you connect to the Internet (it is a “dynamic” address). Note, however, that if you have
label: BODY

text: a broadband connection, depending on your individual circumstance, it is possible that your IP Address
label: BODY

text: that we collect, or even perhaps a cookie we use, may contain information that could be deemed
label: BODY

text: identifiable.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: This is because with some broadband connections your IP Address doesn’t change (it is “static”) and
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: information on use and to help improve the website.

label: BODY

text: 18. We do not collect personally identifiable information from any person we actually know is an individual

text: Privacy Policy Example B
label: HH1

text: XYZ Safe Harbor Policy
label: HH1

text: Introduction
label: H4

text: XYZ, Inc. (the “Company”) is a leading pure-play managed services provider that offers security
label: BODY

text: assessment, detection and prevention services that help companies, governments and organizations
label: BODY

text: safeguard their computer networks and systems. Protecting consumer privacy is important to the
label: BODY

text: Company. The Company and its affiliated United States subsidiaries (hereinafter collectively referred to
label: BODY

text: as the “Company,” “we,” “us” or “our”) adhere to the Safe Harbor Frameworks concerning the transfer of
label: BODY

text: personal data from the European Union (“EU”) and Switzerland to the United States of America.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, we follow the Safe Harbor Privacy Principles published by the U.S. Department of
label: BODY

text: Commerce (the “Principles”) with respect to all such data. If there is any conflict between the policies in
label: BODY

text: this privacy policy and the Principles, the Principles shall govern. This privacy policy outlines our general
label: BODY

text: policy and practices for implementing the Principles, including the types of information we gather, how we
label: BODY

text: use it and the notice and choice affected individuals have regarding our use of and their ability to correct
label: BODY

text: that information. This privacy policy applies to all personal information received by the Company whether
label: BODY

text: in electronic, paper or verbal format.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Definitions
label: BODY

text: “Personal Information” or “Information” means information that (1) is transferred from the EU and
label: BODY

text: Switzerland to the United States; (2) is recorded in any form; (3) is about, or pertains to a specific
label: BODY

text: individual; and (4) can be linked to that individual.
label: BODY

text: “Sensitive Personal Information” means personal information that reveals race, ethnic origin, sexual
label: BODY

text: orientation, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership or that concerns
label: BODY

text: an individual’s health.
label: BODY

text: Principles
label: BODY

text: Notice
label: BODY

text: Company shall inform an individual of the purpose for which it collects and uses the Personal Information
label: BODY

text: and the types of non-agent third parties to which the Company discloses or may disclose that Information.
label: BODY

text: Company shall provide the individual with the choice and means for limiting the use and disclosure of
label: BODY

text: their Personal Information. Notice will be provided in clear and conspicuous language when individuals
label: BODY

text: are first asked to provide Personal Information to the Company, or as soon as practicable thereafter, and
label: BODY

text: in any event before the Company uses or discloses the Information for a purpose other than for which it
label: BODY

text: was originally collected.
label: BODY

text: Choice
label: BODY

text: The Company will offer individuals the opportunity to choose (opt out) whether their Personal Information
label: BODY

text: Appendix C: Dispute Resolution and Enforcement Options
label: HH3

text: Under the Safe Harbor Enforcement Principle, organizations self-certifying to one or both of the Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor Frameworks must establish an independent recourse mechanism (i.e. third party dispute
label: BODY

text: resolution provider) to investigate unresolved complaints. An organization wishing to self-certify must
label: BODY

text: ensure that a suitable mechanism is in place prior to self-certification.
label: BODY

text: If an organization’s self-certification covers human resources data received from Switzerland and/or the
label: BODY

text: EU/EEA regarding its own employees (i.e. organization human resources data, as opposed to
label: BODY

text: customer/client human resources data), then it must agree to cooperate and comply with the Swiss
label: BODY

text: Federal Data Protection and Information Commissioner (FDPIC) and/or the EU data protection authorities
label: BODY

text: (DPAs) with respect to such data.
label: BODY

text: Provision has also been made for organizations to choose, even where organization human resources
label: BODY

text: data are not involved, to cooperate with the appropriate data protection authorities in order to satisfy the
label: BODY

text: Enforcement Principle’s dispute resolution and remedy requirements.
label: BODY

text: In short, where an organization’s self-certification does not cover organization human resources data it
label: BODY

text: may meet the relevant requirements by:
label: BODY

text: a) Putting in place a suitable private sector developed mechanism; or
label: BODY

text: b) Cooperating and complying with the appropriate data protection authorities
label: BODY

text: In contrast, where an organization’s self-certification does cover organization human resources data it
label: BODY

text: may meet the relevant requirements by:
label: BODY

text: a) Cooperating and complying with the appropriate data protection authorities with respect to all
label: BODY

text: types of data; or
label: BODY

text: b) Cooperating and complying with the appropriate data protection authorities exclusively with
label: BODY

text: respect to organization human resources data and using a suitable private sector developed
label: BODY

text: mechanism for all other types of data (e.g. customer/client, clinical trial, etc.)
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification

text: BBB EU Safe Harbor Dispute Resolution Procedure
label: BODY

text: The Council of Better Business Bureaus (“BBB”) is an unbiased organization that fosters honest and
label: BODY

text: responsive relationships between businesses and consumers– instilling consumer confidence and
label: BODY

text: contributing to a trustworthy marketplace. BBB provides objective advice, free business Reliability
label: BODY

text: Reports and charity Wise Giving Reports, and educational information on topics affecting marketplace
label: BODY

text: trust. To further promote trust, BBB also offers complaint and dispute resolution support for consumers
label: BODY

text: and businesses when there is difference in viewpoints.
label: BODY

text: The BBB EU Safe Harbor Dispute Resolution Procedure (“Procedure”) fulfills the dispute resolution
label: BODY

text: mechanism requirement of the Department of Commerce’s Safe Harbor Certification Program. As a
label: BODY

text: recognized leader in business-to-consumer dispute resolution programs, the BBB provides for the review
label: BODY

text: of complaints filed by EU citizens alleging that a business participating in the Procedure has failed to
label: BODY

text: comply with the Safe Harbor Privacy Principles.
label: BODY

text: In the event that the BBB Procedure receives a complaint from an EU citizen, the first step in the dispute
label: BODY

text: resolution process is for the BBB Procedure to contact the business. The BBB Procedure will ensure that
label: BODY

text: the complainant has made a good faith effort to resolve his or her claim directly with the business, and
label: BODY

text: then will attempt an informal mediation between the EU citizen and the business with the goal of rectifying
label: BODY

text: the EU citizen’s concern.
label: BODY

text: If the BBB Procedure is unable to address the EU citizen’s concerns informally with the business, the
label: BODY

text: second step is the more formal Data Privacy Review (“Review”). In the Review, the complainant submits
label: BODY

text: a statement of his or her complaint, which is forwarded to the business. The business replies with an
label: BODY

text: answer. Each party has one further opportunity to respond. When all information has been submitted, the
label: BODY

text: BBB Procedure reviews the information and will issue a decision. If appropriate, the BBB Procedure will
label: BODY

text: recommend corrective action to the business to ensure that all Safe Harbor Privacy Principles are met.
label: BODY

text: The third step in the Procedure is the Data Privacy Appeal. Both parties have the right to appeal the
label: BODY

text: Review decision. In the event of an appeal, the case will be forwarded by the BBB to an independent
label: BODY

text: expert in the privacy field. The appeal will be determined by the expert, who will issue a final decision in
label: BODY

text: the case.
label: BODY
