text: Appendix D: Swiss Economy and Data Protection
label: HH3

text: Switzerland and the United States are bound by close ties. Known as the "Sister Republics," they have a
label: BODY

text: long history of shared democratic values. Both countries rely on an open market economy, support free
label: BODY

text: enterprise, private initiative, a competitive market, and aim at high living standards.
label: BODY

text: Switzerland is not a Member of the European Union. Rooted in tradition and history, the Swiss do not
label: BODY

text: want to give up very comprehensive democratic rights and put a strong emphasis on a very carefully
label: BODY

text: crafted political system establishing a delicate balance between four linguistic and several religious
label: BODY

text: groups. For the time being, they manage their relations with the EU with several economic agreements.
label: BODY

text: Swiss Economy in Brief
label: HH1

text: Switzerland is a small country with a population of only about 7.6 million people, including 1.7 million
label: BODY

text: foreigners. Nevertheless, it is one of the world's most advanced and prosperous nations. Considering
label: BODY

text: GDP per capita, Switzerland is one of the richest countries in the world.
label: BODY

text: Services is the largest sector of the economy with 72% of the labor force, followed by industry (24%) and
label: BODY

text: agriculture (4%). Tourism, financial services, insurance, commerce, transport and health are very
label: BODY

text: important branches of the tertiary sector. The industrial sector has become very specialized in the past
label: BODY

text: twenty years. Swiss machinery, pharmaceuticals, chemicals, medical instruments and watches are sold
label: BODY

text: all around the globe. Swiss manufacturing has a worldwide reputation for high-quality standards, reliability
label: BODY

text: and diligence, accounts for 20% of GDP and is thus pivotal in creating jobs and wealth. Switzerland aims
label: BODY

text: at maintaining in the future a strong manufacturing sector because it is essential for keeping, in turn, a
label: BODY

text: strong services sector.
label: BODY

text: U.S.-Swiss Economic Relations
label: HH1

text: Switzerland is the 16th largest foreign market for the U.S. - ahead of India, Italy and Russia4. On the other
label: BODY

text: hand, the U.S. is the second most important export market for Switzerland. Bilateral trade flows are
label: BODY

text: significant: in 2010, Swiss exports to the U.S. amounted to USD 19.1 billion, while imports from the U.S.
label: BODY

text: to Switzerland added up to USD 20.7 billion. Switzerland imports more goods from the U.S. than Austria,
label: BODY

text: Denmark, Finland, Norway and Portugal combined!
label: BODY

text: 4 Source of data in this section: U.S. Department of Commerce, Bureau of Economic Analysis
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Regarding trade in services, Switzerland is the 8th largest export market for the U.S. (2010: USD 20.3 bn)
label: BODY

text: - ahead of France, India, and Brazil. Conversely, Switzerland is the 6th largest provider of services to the
label: BODY

text: USA. With a value of USD 19.7 billion, Switzerland outpaces Mexico, France, China, and India.
label: BODY

text: Swiss-U.S. investment relations are very strong. Attracted by excellent infrastructure, highly-educated
label: BODY

text: work force and a favorable tax and regulatory environment, numerous U.S. firms have established
label: BODY

text: operations in Switzerland. U.S. direct investment stock in Switzerland is estimated at USD 143.6 billion;
label: BODY

text: more than in China, Brazil, and Russia combined! At the same time, many Swiss firms show a significant
label: BODY

text: presence in the U.S. With an estimated direct investment stock of USD 140.7 billion (2009), a figure
label: BODY

text: equivalent to about 7% of all foreign direct investments in the U.S., Switzerland is the 8th most important
label: BODY

text: foreign direct investor in the U.S..
label: BODY

text: Over the years, Switzerland and the U.S. have concluded numerous agreements and have strengthened
label: BODY

text: their ties with a Joint Economic Commission (2000) dealing with broad strategic issues, a Trade and
label: BODY

text: Investment Cooperation Forum (2006) focusing on market access for firms and cooperation schemes,
label: BODY

text: and, a political dialogue (2006) in areas of common interest such as democracy and security.
label: BODY

text: Swiss Federal Act on Data Protection
label: HH1

text: Switzerland and the United States take different approaches when it comes to the protection of privacy.
label: BODY

text: The U.S. uses a sectoral approach that relies on a mix of legislation, regulation, and self-regulation.
label: BODY

text: Switzerland, however, relies on comprehensive legislation that requires an independent government data
label: BODY

text: protection agency, registration of data bases with this agency, and in some cases prior information before
label: BODY

text: personal data processing may begin. For a better understanding of the Swiss approach regarding
label: BODY

text: personal data protection, it may be worthwhile to highlight the key elements of the Swiss Federal Data
label: BODY

text: Protection Act (FADP).
label: BODY

text: The purpose of the FADP is to protect the privacy, interests, and fundamental rights of data subjects.
label: BODY

text: Furthermore, it has as its central goal the maintenance of good data file practice; and the facilitation of
label: BODY

text: international data exchange by providing a comparable level of protection.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: In Switzerland, the right to privacy is guaranteed in article 13 of the Swiss Federal Constitution. The
label: BODY

text: Federal Data Protection Act (FADP) and the Swiss Federal Data Protection Ordinance (DPO) entered into
label: BODY

text: force on July 1, 1993. The FADP extends the protection of private persons (natural and legal persons)
label: BODY

text: provided by the Swiss Civil Code (SCC) and regulates in a more detailed manner the processing of data
label: BODY

text: by Federal authorities. The FADP, however, does not apply to the Cantons. The Cantons have their own
label: BODY

text: data protection legislation. The FADP provides an overall framework and deals with data protection using
label: BODY

text: principles similar to those applied in other countries (especially in the EU). Private persons need no
label: BODY

text: authorization to process data and registration with the Federal Data Register is required only in certain
label: BODY

text: specific cases. The law covers both the private and public sector, in order to ensure harmonized
label: BODY

text: development and to facilitate the access of individuals to the data protection system.
label: BODY

text: On March 24, 2006, a revision of the FADP as well as a federal decree were adopted, strengthening the
label: BODY

text: position of data subjects by requiring greater transparency in the processing of personal data. In
label: BODY

text: particular, it introduces a duty of information towards data subjects when collecting personal data that are
label: BODY

text: either especially sensitive or concern a personality profile. New rules also apply to the cross-border
label: BODY

text: transfer of data. As a result, it is no longer necessary to report the transmission of personal data that are
label: BODY

text: sent outside Switzerland as long as the receiving country guarantees adequate data protection.
label: BODY

text: Provisions relating to the notification of data files have been adapted to the new transparency
label: BODY

text: requirements. A new and innovative provision introduces the possibility of obtaining the certification of
label: BODY

text: personal data processing products and systems, and, under certain conditions, requires the owners of
label: BODY

text: data sets to designate a data protection officer. Last, but not least, the Swiss Federal Data Protection and
label: BODY

text: Information Commissioner (FDPIC) is empowered to appeal any order of the Federal Chancellery or of
label: BODY

text: the Departments (Ministries) if a recommendation he has made is rejected. He also might refer a matter
label: BODY

text: to the Federal Administrative Court for a decision if a private person does not comply with or rejects a
label: BODY

text: recommendation. These changes have been in effect since 1st January 2008.
label: BODY

text: Main Provisions of the Federal Data Protection Act
label: BODY

text: The FADP is very wide in its scope and applies to processing of personal data carried out by Federal
label: BODY

text: authorities, private organizations (including legal persons), and individual private persons (excluding
label: BODY

text: those for normal private purposes). Data collections kept by journalists and by the media are covered
label: BODY

text: under Art. 10, and benefit from several exemptions (i.e. provisions regarding freedom of the press and
label: BODY

text: speech).
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: The law covers data relating to both private and legal persons and applies to electronic data processing
label: BODY

text: (EDP) as well as manual files (Art. 2, Art. 3 para. a). Sensitive data - such as that relating to religion,
label: BODY

text: political beliefs, trade union activities, health, race, social assistance or criminal records - enjoy more
label: BODY

text: enhanced protection in various respects.
label: BODY

text: Any data processing must ensure accuracy and be balanced. The collection of personal data and in
label: BODY

text: particular the purpose of its processing must be evident to the data subject (Art.4 para. 4). In the case of
label: BODY

text: processing of sensitive personal data or personality profiles, the data subject must give its explicit
label: BODY

text: consent. Furthermore, data must be secured against unauthorized access (Art. 7), and data subjects
label: BODY

text: must have a right of access (Art. 8) and have the right to correct errors (Art. 5).
label: BODY

text: The processing of personal data may be assigned to third parties by agreement or by law if the data is
label: BODY

text: processed only in the manner permitted for the instructing party itself and if it is not prohibited by a
label: BODY

text: statutory or contractual duty of confidentiality (Art. 10a). In addition, the instructing party must in particular
label: BODY

text: ensure that the third party guarantees data security.
label: BODY

text: All data files held by Federal authorities must be registered with the Federal Data Protection and
label: BODY

text: Information Commissioner (FDPIC). Private persons only have to register data collections if they include
label: BODY

text: sensitive data or if the data is communicated regularly to third persons, and where the file controller is not
label: BODY

text: under a legal obligation to process the data. With the revision of the FADP, the notification procedure has
label: BODY

text: been simplified and the owners of data sets can register on line.
label: BODY

text: The demand for more transparency in data processing (Art. 4, para. 4, Art. 14) also has an impact on the
label: BODY

text: duty to register data collections. Federal bodies must continue to register their data collections as in the
label: BODY

text: past. However, the requirement has been extended to cover the private sector. As a result, all owners of
label: BODY

text: data sets will be required to register their collections if they regularly process highly sensitive personal
label: BODY

text: data or personality profiles, or if they regularly disclose personal data to third parties, even if the persons
label: BODY

text: concerned have been duly informed. As a result, it is now compulsory to register all data collections which
label: BODY

text: were not subject to a registration obligation before the entry into force of the revised FADP. Data
label: BODY

text: collections will have to be registered before they can be opened (Art. 11a, para. 4).
label: BODY

text: However, the law also provides for certain exceptions to the compulsory registration requirement (Art.
label: BODY

text: 11a, para. 5). The Federal Council established the detailed rules relating to the implementation in the
label: BODY

text: DPO.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Cross-border Data Transfers
label: BODY

text: The FADP regulates the transborder transfer of data in those cases when there is a need for the
label: BODY

text: protection of privacy. The transfer of data abroad is not permitted if adequate data protection cannot be
label: BODY

text: assured (Art. 6 para. 1). Art. 6 FADP needed to be adapted in 2006 as a consequence of the decree of
label: BODY

text: the Council of Europe Convention on the Protection of Individuals with regard to Automatic Processing of
label: BODY

text: Personnel Data (Convention ETS 108). The Convention aims at a comparable level of data protection at
label: BODY

text: the highest level possible, and unrestricted transborder data transfer between contracting states; as well
label: BODY

text: as a guarantee that the transfer of personal data to a data recipient who is not covered by the Convention
label: BODY

text: will only be authorized if the recipient state or the recipient organization can guarantee an appropriate
label: BODY

text: level of protection.
label: BODY

text: The notification under the former FADP that required the disclosure of transborder data transfer has been
label: BODY

text: replaced by the duty of care and a selective duty to inform (Art. 6 para. 3 FADP). In general, this means
label: BODY

text: that private individuals and federal bodies transferring data abroad must comply with the principles of
label: BODY

text: FADP (Art. 4 FADP), ensure data security and the right to information of persons whose data is being
label: BODY

text: transferred. If data protection cannot be guaranteed, it must be secured through other guarantees
label: BODY

text: according to Art. 6 para. 2 FADP. The appropriateness of protection in the legislation of the target country
label: BODY

text: is ensured when it is in accordance with the principles set out in Convention ETS 108. In order to
label: BODY

text: ascertain compliance with the appropriateness principle, the data exporter may rely on the list of states
label: BODY

text: published by the FDPIC (http://www.edoeb.admin.ch/themen/00794/00827/index.html?lang=en). The list
label: BODY

text: includes states which are contracting parties to Convention ETS 108 and the additional Protocol, or
label: BODY

text: according to the FDPIC, provide an adequate level of data protection.
label: BODY

text: of 19 June 1992 (Status as of 1 January 2011)
label: BODY

text: The Federal Assembly of the Swiss Confederation,
label: BODY

text: based on Articles 95, 122 and 173 paragraph 2 of the Federal Constitution5,6 and having regard to the
label: BODY

text: Federal Council Dispatch dated 23 March 19887, decrees:
label: BODY

text: Section 1: Aim, Scope and Definitions
label: HH1

text: Art. 1 Aim
label: BODY

text: This Act aims to protect the privacy and the fundamental rights of persons when their data is processed.
label: BODY

text: Art. 2 Scope
label: BODY

text: 1) This Act applies to the processing of data pertaining to natural persons and legal persons by:
label: BODY

text: private persons;
label: BODY

text: federal bodies.
label: BODY

text: 2) It does not apply to:
label: BODY

text: personal data that is processed by a natural person exclusively for personal use and
label: BODY

text: which is not disclosed to outsiders;
label: BODY

text: deliberations of the Federal Assembly and in parliamentary committees;
label: BODY

text: pending civil proceedings, criminal proceedings, international mutual assistance
label: BODY

text: proceedings and proceedings under constitutional or under administrative law, with the exception
label: BODY

text: of administrative proceedings of first instance;
label: BODY

text: SR 101
label: BODY

text: Amended in accordance with No. 3 of the Federal Act of 19 March 2010 on the Implementation of Framework Decision 2008/977/JHA on
label: BODY

text: the protection of personal data processed in the framework of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, in force since 1 Dec. 2010

text: BBl 1988 II 413

text: U.S. Department of Commerce

text: public registers based on private law;
label: BODY

text: personal data processed by the International Committee of the Red Cross.

text: Art. 3 Definitions
label: BODY

text: The following definitions apply:
label: BODY

text: personal data (data): all information relating to an identified or identifiable person;
label: BODY

text: data subjects: natural or legal persons whose data is processed;
label: BODY

text: sensitive personal data: data on:
label: BODY

text: religious, ideological, political or trade union-related views or activities,
label: BODY

text: health, the intimate sphere or the racial origin,
label: BODY

text: social security measures,
label: BODY

text: administrative or criminal proceedings and sanctions;
label: BODY

text: personality profile: a collection of data that permits an assessment of essential
label: BODY

text: characteristics of the personality of a natural person;
label: BODY

text: processing: any operation with personal data, irrespective of the means applied and the
label: BODY

text: procedure, and in particular the collection, storage, use, revision, disclosure, archiving or
label: BODY

text: destruction of data;
label: BODY

text: disclosure: making personal data accessible, for example by permitting access,
label: BODY

text: transmission or publication;
label: BODY

text: data file: any set of personal data that is structured in such a way that the data is
label: BODY

text: accessible by data subject;
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: federal bodies: federal authorities and services as well as persons who are entrusted with
label: BODY

text: federal public tasks;
label: BODY

text: controller of the data file: private persons or federal bodies that decide on the purpose
label: BODY

text: and content of a data file;
label: BODY

text: formal enactment:
label: BODY

text: federal acts,
label: BODY

text: decrees of international organizations that are binding on Switzerland and
label: BODY

text: international treaties containing legal rules that are approved by the Federal Assembly;
label: BODY

text: Section 2: General Data Protection Provisions
label: HH1

text: Art. 4 Principles
label: BODY

text: 1) Personal data may only be processed lawfully.11
label: BODY

text: 2) Its processing must be carried out in good faith and must be proportionate.
label: BODY

text: 3) Personal data may only be processed for the purpose indicated at the time of collection, that is evident
label: BODY

text: from the circumstances, or that is provided for by law.
label: BODY

text: 4) The collection of personal data and in particular the purpose of its processing must be evident to the
label: BODY

text: data subject.12
label: BODY

text: 5) If the consent of the data subject is required for the processing of personal data, such consent is valid
label: BODY

text: only if given voluntarily on the provision of adequate information. Additionally, consent must be given
label: BODY

text: expressly in the case of processing of sensitive personal data or personality profiles.13
label: BODY

text: Amended in accordance with No. I of the Federal Act of 24 March 2006, in force since 1 Jan. 2008 (AS 2007 4983 4991; BBl 2003 2101).
label: BODY

text: Art. 5 Correctness of the data
label: BODY

text: 1) Anyone who processes personal data must make certain that it is correct. He must take all reasonable
label: BODY

text: measures to ensure that data that is incorrect or incomplete in view of the purpose of its collection is
label: BODY

text: either corrected or destroyed.14
label: BODY

text: 2) Any data subject may request that incorrect data be corrected.
label: BODY

text: Art. 615 Cross-border disclosure
label: BODY

text: 1) Personal data may not be disclosed abroad if the privacy of the data subjects would be seriously
label: BODY

text: endangered thereby, in particular due to the absence of legislation that guarantees adequate protection.
label: BODY

text: 2) In the absence of legislation that guarantees adequate protection, personal data may be disclosed
label: BODY

text: abroad only if:
label: BODY

text: sufficient safeguards, in particular contractual clauses, ensure an adequate level of
label: BODY

text: protection abroad;
label: BODY

text: the data subject has consented in the specific case;
label: BODY

text: the processing is directly connected with the conclusion or the performance of a contract
label: BODY

text: and the personal data is that of a contractual party;
label: BODY

text: disclosure is essential in the specific case in order either to safeguard an overriding
label: BODY

text: public interest or for the establishment, exercise or enforcement of legal claims before the courts;
label: BODY

text: disclosure is required in the specific case in order to protect the life or the physical
label: BODY

text: integrity of the data subject;
label: BODY

text: Second sentence inserted by No. I of the Federal Act of 24 March 2006, in force since 1 Jan. 2008 (AS 2007 4983 4991; BBl 2003 2101).

text: its processing;
label: BODY

text: disclosure is made within the same legal person or company or between legal persons or
label: BODY

text: companies that are under the same management, provided those involved are subject to data
label: BODY

text: protection rules that ensure an adequate level of protection.
label: BODY

text: 3) The Federal Data Protection and Information Commissioner (the Commissioner, Art. 26) must be
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Art. 7 Data security
label: BODY

text: 1) Personal data must be protected against unauthorized processing through adequate technical and
label: BODY

text: organizational measures.
label: BODY

text: 2) The Federal Council issues detailed provisions on the minimum standards for data security.
label: BODY

text: Art. 7a16

text: Art. 8 Right to information
label: BODY

text: 1) Any person may request information from the controller of a data file as to whether data concerning
label: BODY

text: them is being processed.
label: BODY

text: 2) The controller of a data file must notify the data subject:17
label: BODY

text: of all available data concerning the subject in the data file, including the available
label: BODY

text: information on the source of the data;
label: BODY

text: the purpose of and if applicable the legal basis for the processing as well as the
label: BODY

text: categories of the personal data processed, the other parties involved with the file and the data
label: BODY

text: recipient.

text: 3) The controller of a data file may arrange for data on the health of the data subject to be communicated
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 4) If the controller of a data file has personal data processed by a third party, the controller remains under
label: BODY

text: an obligation to provide information. The third party is under an obligation to provide information if he
label: BODY

text: does not disclose the identity of the controller or if the controller is not domiciled in Switzerland.
label: BODY

text: 5) The information must normally be provided in writing, in the form of a printout or a photocopy, and is
label: BODY

text: free of charge. The Federal Council regulates exceptions.
label: BODY

text: 6) No one may waive the right to information in advance.
label: BODY

text: Art. 919 Limitation of the duty to provide information
label: BODY

text: 1) The controller of a data file may refuse, restrict or defer the provision of information where:
label: BODY

text: a formal enactment so provides;
label: BODY

text: this is required to protect the overriding interests of third parties.
label: BODY

text: 2) A federal body may further refuse, restrict or defer the provision of information where:
label: BODY

text: this is required to protect overriding public interests, and in particular the internal or
label: BODY

text: external security of the Confederation;
label: BODY

text: the information would jeopardize the outcome of a criminal investigation or any other
label: BODY

text: investigation proceedings.
label: BODY

text: 3) As soon as the reason for refusing, restricting or deferring the provision of information ceases to apply,
label: BODY

text: the federal body must provide the information unless this is impossible or only possible with
label: BODY

text: disproportionate inconvenience or expense.
label: BODY

text: 4) The private controller of a data file may further refuse, restrict or defer the provision of information
label: BODY

text: where his own overriding interests so require and he does not disclose the personal data to third parties.

text: Art. 10 Limitations of the right to information for journalists
label: BODY

text: 1) The controller of a data file that is used exclusively for publication in the edited section of a periodically

text: Art. 10a20 Data processing by third parties
label: BODY

text: 1) The processing of personal data may be assigned to third parties by agreement or by law if:
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: it is not prohibited by a statutory or contractual duty of confidentiality.
label: BODY

text: 2) The instructing party must in particular ensure that the third party guarantees data security.
label: BODY

text: 3) Third parties may claim the same justification as the instructing party.

text: Art. 1121 Certification procedure
label: BODY

text: 1) In order to improve data protection and data security, the manufacturers of data processing systems or

text: Section 3: Processing of Personal Data by Private Persons
label: HH1

text: Art. 12 Breaches of privacy
label: BODY

text: 1) Anyone who processes personal data must not unlawfully breach the privacy of the data subjects in
label: BODY

text: doing so.
label: BODY

text: 2) In particular, he must not:
label: BODY

text: process personal data in contravention of the principles of Articles 4, 5 paragraph 1 and 7
label: BODY

text: paragraph 1;
label: BODY

text: process data pertaining to a person against that person’s express wish without
label: BODY

text: justification;
label: BODY

text: disclose sensitive personal data or personality profiles to third parties without
label: BODY

text: justification.23
label: BODY

text: 3) Normally there is no breach of privacy if the data subject has made the data generally accessible and
label: BODY

text: has not expressly prohibited its processing.
label: BODY

text: Amended in accordance with No. I of the Federal Act of 24 March 2006, in force since 1 Jan. 2008 (AS 2007 4983 4991; BBl 2003 2101).

text: Art. 13 Justification
label: BODY

text: 1) A breach of privacy is unlawful unless it is justified by the consent of the injured party, by an overriding
label: BODY

text: private or public interest or by law.
label: BODY

text: 2) An overriding interest of the person processing the data shall in particular be considered if that person:
label: BODY

text: processes personal data in direct connection with the conclusion or the performance of a
label: BODY

text: contract and the personal data is that of a contractual party;
label: BODY

text: is or intends to be in commercial competition with another and for this purpose processes
label: BODY

text: personal data without disclosing the data to third parties;
label: BODY

text: process data that is neither sensitive personal data nor a personality profile in order to
label: BODY

text: verify the creditworthiness of another, and discloses such data to third parties only if the data is
label: BODY

text: required for the conclusion or the performance of a contract with the data subject;
label: BODY

text: processes personal data on a professional basis exclusively for publication in the edited
label: BODY

text: section of a periodically published medium;
label: BODY

text: processes personal data for purposes not relating to a specific person, in particular for
label: BODY

text: the purposes of research, planning and statistics and publishes the results in such a manner that
label: BODY

text: the data subjects may not be identified;
label: BODY

text: collects data on a person of public interest, provided the data relates to the public
label: BODY

text: activities of that person.

text: 1) Actions relating to protection of privacy are governed by Articles 28, 28a and 28l of the Civil Code26.

label: BODY

text: 1) The federal body that processes or arranges for the processing of personal data in fulfillment of its

text: Appendix E: U.S.-EU Safe Harbor Framework
label: HH3

text: Background on the U.S.-EU Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: The European Commission’s Directive on Data Protection (the Directive) went into effect in October 1998,
label: BODY

text: and would prohibit the transfer of personal data to non-European Union countries that do not meet the
label: BODY

text: European Union (EU) “adequacy” standard for privacy protection.
label: BODY

text: While the United States and the EU share the goal of enhancing privacy protection for their citizens, the
label: BODY

text: United States takes a different approach to privacy from that taken by the EU. The United States uses a
label: BODY

text: sectoral approach that relies on a mix of legislation, regulation, and self-regulation. The EU, however,
label: BODY

text: relies on comprehensive legislation that requires, among other things, the creation of independent
label: BODY

text: government data protection agencies, registration of databases with those agencies, and in some
label: BODY

text: instances prior approval before personal data processing may begin. As a result of these differences, the
label: BODY

text: Directive could have significantly hampered the ability of U.S. organizations to engage in a range of trans-
label: BODY

text: Atlantic transactions.
label: BODY

text: In order to bridge these differences and provide a streamlined and cost-effective means for U.S.
label: BODY

text: organizations to satisfy the Directive’s “adequacy” requirement, the U.S. Department of Commerce in
label: BODY

text: consultation with the European Commission developed a "Safe Harbor" framework. The U.S.-EU Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor Framework, which was approved by the EU in 2000, is an important way for U.S. organizations to
label: BODY

text: avoid experiencing interruptions in their business dealings with the EU or facing prosecution by EU
label: BODY

text: Member State authorities under EU Member State privacy laws. Self-certifying to the U.S.-EU Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor Framework will ensure that EU organizations know that your organization provides "adequate"
label: BODY

text: privacy protection, as defined by the Directive.
label: BODY

text: U.S.-EU Safe Harbor Benefits
label: BODY

text: Benefits for participating U.S. organizations include:
label: BODY

text: All 27 EU Member States are bound by the European Commission’s finding of “adequacy” and
label: BODY

text: Iceland, Liechtenstein, and Norway are bound by the European Economic Area (EEA)’s
label: BODY

text: recognition of “adequacy”;
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Organizations participating in the U.S.-EU Safe Harbor program will be deemed to provide
label: BODY

text: “adequate” privacy protection;
label: BODY

text: Member State requirements for prior approval of data transfers either will be waived or approval
label: BODY

text: will be automatically granted;
label: BODY

text: Claims brought by EU citizens against U.S. organizations will be heard, subject to limited
label: BODY

text: exceptions, in the U.S.; and
label: BODY

text: Compliance requirements are streamlined and cost-effective, which should particularly benefit
label: BODY

text: small and medium enterprises.
label: BODY

text: An EU organization can ensure that it is sending information to a U.S. organization participating in the
label: BODY

text: U.S.-EU Safe Harbor program by viewing the public list of Safe Harbor organizations posted on the Safe
label: BODY

text: Harbor website. This list contains the names of all U.S. organizations that have self-certified to the U.S.-
label: BODY

text: EU Safe Harbor Framework. This list will be regularly updated, so that it is clear which organizations are
label: BODY

text: assured of Safe Harbor benefits.
label: BODY

text: Please note that an organization does not have to self-certify compliance with the U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor
label: BODY

text: Framework in order to self-certify compliance with the U.S.-EU Safe Harbor Framework and vice versa.
label: BODY

text: Although the respective sets of Safe Harbor Privacy Principles, frequently asked questions and answers
label: BODY

text: (FAQs), and enforcement statements of the two Safe Harbor Frameworks are similar, they differ in a
label: BODY

text: number of ways. Understanding the Safe Harbor Frameworks requires familiarity with all of the relevant
label: BODY

text: documents.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Appendix F: Glossary*
label: HH3

text: Access – The ability to view personal information held by an organization – this ability may be
label: BODY

text: complemented by an ability to update or correct the information. Access defines the intersection of
label: BODY

text: identity and data; that is, who can do what to which data.
label: BODY

text: Adequacy – Adequacy refers to the recognition of the existence of a legal regime in another country that
label: BODY

text: provides sufficient protection for personal information. The Swiss Federal Act on Data Protection (FADP)
label: BODY

text: provides that “personal data may not be disclosed abroad if the privacy of the data subjects would be
label: BODY

text: seriously endangered thereby, in particular due to the absence of legislation that guarantees adequate
label: BODY

text: protection.” As used in the EU Data Protection Directive, a country will be deemed “adequate” if its laws
label: BODY

text: afford individuals rights that are similar to those afforded by the EU Data Protection Directive. In the EU
label: BODY

text: context, if a country offers adequate protection, then data transfers from the European Economic Area
label: BODY

text: (EEA) to that country may occur without any further limitation – provided that the processing meets the
label: BODY

text: other provisions of the EU Directive. The adequacy concept has been expanded to encompass other
label: BODY

text: types of data transfer mechanisms. For example, the U.S.-Swiss and U.S.-EU Safe Harbor Frameworks
label: BODY

text: provide an adequate level of protection, so companies that are in the relevant Safe Harbor may transfer
label: BODY

text: data from Switzerland and/or the European Union to the United States.
label: BODY

text: Choice – An individual’s ability to determine whether or how personal information collected from him or
label: BODY

text: her may be used or disclosed by the entity that collected the information. Also: The ability of an individual
label: BODY

text: to limit certain uses of his or her personal information. For example, an individual may have choice about
label: BODY

text: whether to permit a company to contact the individual or share the individual’s data with third parties.
label: BODY

text: Data commissioner◊ – Government official that runs a data protection office and that is charged with
label: BODY

text: enforcing a country’s data protection laws. According to the FADP the Federal Data Protection and
label: BODY

text: Information Commissioner (FDPIC) “fulfills his tasks independently without being subject to the Directives
label: BODY

text: of any authority.” These tasks include supervising compliance by federal bodies with the FADP and other
label: BODY

text: federal data protection regulations, advising private persons on data protection matters, and investigating
label: BODY

text: and making recommendations regarding the private sector. As relates to the private sector, the FDPIC is
label: BODY

text: authorized to investigate whether methods of processing are capable of breaching the privacy of large
label: BODY

text: numbers of persons, data files must be registered or there is a duty to provide information.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: On the basis of his investigations, the FDPIC may recommend that the method of processing be changed
label: BODY

text: or abandoned. If the recommendation made by the FDPIC is not complied with or rejected, he may refer
label: BODY

text: the matter to the Federal Administrative Court for a decision. Included in its list of tasks is the provision of
label: BODY

text: its expert opinion on the extent to which foreign data protection legislation guarantees adequate
label: BODY

text: protection.
label: BODY

text: Data controller – A controller is any person who makes decisions with regard to the processing of
label: BODY

text: personal data, including decisions about the purposes for which the personal data are processed and the
label: BODY

text: manner in which the personal data are processed. The FADP defines a “controller of the data file” as:
label: BODY

text: “private persons or federal bodies that decide on the purpose and content of a data file.” The EU Directive
label: BODY

text: defines a data “controller” as: “the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or any other body
label: BODY

text: which alone or jointly with others determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data;
label: BODY

text: where the purposes and means of processing are determined by national or community laws or
label: BODY

text: regulations, the controller or the specific criteria for his nomination may be designated by national or
label: BODY

text: community law.”
label: BODY

text: Data processor – A data processor is a person who processes the data on behalf of the data controller,
label: BODY

text: but who is under the authority of the data controller. The EU Directive defines data “processor” as: “a
label: BODY

text: natural or legal person, public authority, agency or any other body which processes personal data on
label: BODY

text: behalf of the controller.”
label: BODY

text: Data protection – The management of personal information. In the United States, “privacy” is the term
label: BODY

text: that is used in policies, laws, and regulations. In contrast, in Switzerland, the European Union, and other
label: BODY

text: countries, the term “data protection” often identifies privacy-related laws and regulations.
label: BODY

text: Data protection authority – See also Data protection office, Data commissioner.
label: BODY

text: Data protection office – A government agency that enforces data protection legislation. According to the
label: BODY

text: EU Directive: “Each member state shall provide that one or more public authorities are responsible for
label: BODY

text: monitoring the application within its territory of the provisions adopted by the member states pursuant to
label: BODY

text: this Directive. These authorities shall act with complete independence in exercising the functions
label: BODY

text: entrusted to them.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Each authority has investigative powers necessary for the performance of its supervisory duties, power to
label: BODY

text: engage in legal proceedings in case of violations. Each supervisory authority shall hear claims lodged by
label: BODY

text: any person, or by an association representing that person.”  See also Data protection authority, Data
label: BODY

text: commissioner.
label: BODY

text: Data subject – Term used in some data protection litigation to describe an individual who is the subject
label: BODY

text: of a personal data record.
label: BODY

text: Deceptive trade practices – In the context of U.S. federal law, a term associated with corporate entities
label: BODY

text: that mislead or misrepresent products or services to consumers and customers. These practices are
label: BODY

text: regulated by the Federal Trade Commission at the federal level and typically by the Attorney General's
label: BODY

text: Office of Consumer Protection at the state level. These laws typically provide both for enforcement by the
label: BODY

text: government to stop the practice and individual actions for damages brought by consumers who are hurt
label: BODY

text: by the practices.
label: BODY

text: Dispute resolution – The response to a valid complaint or grievance, or the action taken to correct faulty
label: BODY

text: information, or to make amends for harm or inconvenience caused to an individual.
label: BODY

text: EU Data Protection Directive (EU Directive) – Several directives deal with personal data usage, but the
label: BODY

text: most important is the general policy approved by the European Commission in 1995 (95/46/EC) which
label: BODY

text: protects individuals’ privacy and personal data use. The EU Directive was adopted in 1995 and became
label: BODY

text: effective in 1998. The EU Directive recognizes the European view that privacy is a fundamental human
label: BODY

text: right, and establishes a general comprehensive legal framework that is aimed at protecting individuals
label: BODY

text: and promoting individual choice regarding the processing of personal data. The EU Directive imposes an
label: BODY

text: onerous set of requirements on any person that collects or processes data pertaining to individuals in
label: BODY

text: their personal or professional capacity. It is based on a set of data protection principles, which include the
label: BODY

text: legitimate basis, purpose limitation, data quality, proportionality, and transparency principles, data
label: BODY

text: security and confidentiality, data subjects’ rights of access, rectification, deletion, and objection,
label: BODY

text: restrictions on onwards transfers, additional protection where special categories of data and direct
label: BODY

text: marketing are involved, and a prohibition on automated individual decisions. The EU Directive applies to
label: BODY

text: all sectors of industry, from financial institutions to consumer goods companies, and from list brokers to
label: BODY

text: any employer. The EU Directive’s key provisions impose serious restrictions on personal data processing,
label: BODY

text: grant individual rights to “data subjects,” and set forth specific procedural obligations, including notification
label: BODY

text: to national authority.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: The EU Directive has been supplemented by additional directives, including a specific provision for the
label: BODY

text: telecommunications sector (2002/58) as well as for e-commerce.
label: BODY

text: European Economic Area (EEA)◊ – The EEA  allows Iceland, Liechtenstein, and Norway to participate
label: BODY

text: in the EU's internal market without a conventional EU membership. These three countries apply EEA law,
label: BODY

text: which is identical to all EU legislation related to the single market, with the exception of legislation on
label: BODY

text: agriculture, fisheries, and fiscal issues. The EEA, however, is not a customs union. Switzerland is not a
label: BODY

text: member of the EEA, but has concluded a large number of bilateral agreements with the EU covering a
label: BODY

text: significant part of EEA law.
label: BODY

text: European Union (EU) – The European Union is an organization of European countries dedicated to
label: BODY

text: increasing economic integration and strengthening cooperation among its members. The European Union
label: BODY

text: was involved in the development of the Safe Harbor Principles that affect data flows from the European
label: BODY

text: Union into the United States. As of July 2008, the member states include: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria,
label: BODY

text: Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy,
label: BODY

text: Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia,
label: BODY

text: Spain, Sweden, and United Kingdom.
label: BODY

text: Federal Trade Commission (FTC) – The U.S. Federal Trade Commission enforces a variety of federal
label: BODY

text: antitrust and consumer protection laws, including the Safe Harbor Principles. The FTC seeks to ensure
label: BODY

text: that the nation’s markets function competitively, and are vigorous, efficient, and free of undue restrictions.
label: BODY

text: The FTC also works to enhance the smooth operation of the marketplace by eliminating acts or practices
label: BODY

text: that are unfair or deceptive.
label: BODY

text: Member state – In EU documents, this term refers to a country that is a full member of the European
label: BODY

text: Union.  See European Union.
label: BODY

text: Notice – A written description of an entity’s practices with respect to its collection, use and disclosure of
label: BODY

text: personal information. A private notice typically includes a description of what personal information the
label: BODY

text: entity collects, how the entity uses the information, with whom it shares the information, whether the
label: BODY

text: information is secured, and whether an individual has any choices as to how the entity uses the
label: BODY

text: information.
label: BODY

text: Opt-in – A consumer’s expression of affirmative consent based upon a specific act of the consumer.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Opt-out – A consumer’s exercise of choice through an affirmative request that a particular use of
label: BODY

text: disclosure of data not occur.
label: BODY

text: Personal data – The FADP defines “personal data (data)” as: “all information relating to an identified or
label: BODY

text: identifiable person.” The EU Directive defines “personal data” as: “any information relating to an identified
label: BODY

text: or identifiable natural person ('data subject')” and explains that an “identifiable person” is “one who can be
label: BODY

text: identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identification number or to one or more
label: BODY

text: factors specific to his physical, physiological, mental, economic, cultural or social identity.”
label: BODY

text: Personal information – Any information that (i) relates to an individual and (ii) identifies or can be used
label: BODY

text: to identify the individual. Such information may include an individual’s name, postal address, e-mail
label: BODY

text: address, telephone number, Social Security number, or other unique identifier.
label: BODY

text: Privacy – The appropriate use of personal information under the circumstances. What is appropriate will
label: BODY

text: depend on context, law, and the individual’s expectations; also, the right of an individual to control the
label: BODY

text: collection, use, and disclosure of personal information.
label: BODY

text: Privacy policy – An organization’s standard pertaining to the user information it collects and what is
label: BODY

text: done with the information after it is collected.
label: BODY

text: Privacy seal program – Self-regulatory regimes that certify compliance with a set of standards of privacy
label: BODY

text: protection. Services provide a “trust” mark, as well as independent verification and remediation and
label: BODY

text: dispute resolution mechanisms for online privacy practices. Websites display the program’s seal to
label: BODY

text: indicate that they adhere to these standards.
label: BODY

text: Privacy statement – An organization’s communication regarding its privacy policies, such as what
label: BODY

text: personal information is collected, how it will be used, with whom it will be shared, and whether one has
label: BODY

text: the option to exercise control over how one’s information is used. Privacy statements are frequently
label: BODY

text: posted on websites.
label: BODY

text: Processing of personal data – The FADP defines “processing” as: “any operation with personal data,
label: BODY

text: irrespective of the means applied and the procedure, and in particular the collection, storage, use,
label: BODY

text: revision, disclosure, archiving or destruction of data.”
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: The EU Directive defines “processing” as: “any operation or set of operations performed upon personal
label: BODY

text: data, whether or not by automatic means, such as collection, recording, organization, storage, adaptation
label: BODY

text: or alteration, retrieval, consultation, use, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making
label: BODY

text: available, alignment or combination, blocking, erasure, or destruction.”
label: BODY

text: Safe Harbor – The EU Directive and the FADP prohibit the transfer of personal data outside of the
label: BODY

text: European Union and Switzerland respectively, to jurisdictions that do not meet the European “adequacy”
label: BODY

text: standard for privacy protection. While the United States, the European Union, and Switzerland share the
label: BODY

text: goal of privacy protection, the United States uses a sectoral approach that relies on a mix of legislation,
label: BODY

text: regulation, and self-regulation, while the European Union and Switzerland rely on comprehensive
label: BODY

text: legislation that requires, among other things, the creation of government data protection agencies. As a
label: BODY

text: result of these different approaches to privacy protection, the EU Directive and the FADP could have
label: BODY

text: significantly hampered the ability of U.S. organizations to engage in many trans-Atlantic transactions.
label: BODY

text: In order to bridge the differences in approach and provide a streamlined means for U.S. organizations to
label: BODY

text: comply with the EU data protection requirements, the U.S. Department of Commerce and the European
label: BODY

text: Commission developed a “Safe Harbor” framework. The U.S.-EU Safe Harbor Framework, which was
label: BODY

text: approved by the EU in 2000, is an important way for U.S. organizations to avoid interruptions in business
label: BODY

text: dealings with the EU.
label: BODY

text: The U.S. Department of Commerce and the Federal Data Protection and Information Commissioner of
label: BODY

text: Switzerland developed a separate “Safe Harbor” framework to bridge the differences in approach and
label: BODY

text: provide a streamlined means for U.S. organizations to comply with Swiss data protection requirements.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Framework, which was approved in 2009, is an important way for U.S.
label: BODY

text: organizations to avoid interruption in business dealings with Switzerland.
label: BODY

text: Self-certifying compliance with one or both of the Safe Harbor Frameworks assures European
label: BODY

text: organizations that an organization provides adequate privacy protection, as defined by the relevant data
label: BODY

text: protection law. From a U.S. perspective, the Safe Harbor program is a self-regulatory regime that is only
label: BODY

text: available to organizations that are subject to the enforcement authority of the U.S. Federal Trade
label: BODY

text: Commission or the U.S. Department of Transportation. Organizations that are outside of the jurisdiction of
label: BODY

text: these two agencies are not eligible to join Safe Harbor.
label: BODY

text: The U.S.-Swiss Safe Harbor Guide to Self-Certification
label: BODY

text: U.S. Department of Commerce
label: BODY

text: Sensitive personal data / sensitive information – The FADP and the EU Directive distinguish between
label: BODY

text: ordinary personal data, such as name, address, and telephone number, and sensitive personal data,
label: BODY

text: defined as racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious beliefs, trade union membership, health, sex
label: BODY

text: life, and criminal convictions. The processing of such data is prohibited unless specifically allowed by law.
label: BODY

text: Special restrictions apply to the processing of such data.
label: BODY

text: Swiss Federal Act on Data Protection (FADP)◊ – The Federal Act on Data Protection (FADP) and the
label: BODY

text: Swiss Federal Data Protection Ordinance entered into force in 1993. In 2006, revisions to the FADP and
label: BODY

text: the federal decree were adopted requiring greater transparency in the processing of personal data.  In
label: BODY

text: Switzerland, the right to privacy is guaranteed in article 13 of the Swiss Federal Constitution. The FADP
label: BODY

text: recognizes the European view that privacy is a fundamental human right, and establishes a general
label: BODY

text: comprehensive legal framework that is aimed at protecting individuals and promoting individual choice
label: BODY

text: regarding the processing of personal data. The law is very wide in its scope and applies to personal data
label: BODY

text: activities carried out by federal authorities, private organizations, and individual private persons
label: BODY

text: (excluding those for normal private purposes). The FADP covers data relating to both private and legal
label: BODY

text: persons and applies to electronic data processing, as well as manual files. The law is based on a set of
label: BODY

text: data protection principles, which includes: legitimate basis and purpose limitation; data quality;
label: BODY

text: transparency; data security; rights of access, rectification, and deletion; restrictions on onward transfers;
label: BODY

text: and additional protection where special categories of data are involved. The FADP’s key provisions grant
label: BODY

text: individual rights to “data subjects”, and set forth specific procedural obligations. Under the FADP, private
label: BODY

text: persons are only required to register their data sets if they regularly process sensitive personal data or
label: BODY

text: personality profiles or if they regularly disclose personal data to third parties, even if the data subjects
label: BODY

text: concerned have been duly informed (certain derogations apply). Although it is no longer necessary to
label: BODY

text: report the transfer of personal data outside of Switzerland, the transfer of such data abroad is only
label: BODY

text: permissible if adequate data protection can be assured.
